Response: no sweetie just stay safe and thank you for this. this was a blessing to me.

Call: okay, so as you know, this study is investigating individual behaviors and beliefs related to having hoarding disorder. the first question would be: what term do you prefer when we refer to your difficulties with clutter and difficulties discarding?
Response: oh, anything you want to call it is fine.

Call: thats completely up to you! some patients dont care and just call it hoarding disorder, some patients call it clutter, so whatever you prefer.
Response: well, clutter, because its not that im trying to keep things  incoherent going through them.

Call: okay so, difficulties with clutter would be your preferred term.
Response: yes.

Call: so, can you please describe your clutter problems and how long this has been going on?
Response: well i mean ive always been messy and cluttered, even when i was a child, you know, i would just stuff things in the drawers and whatever. and im pretty sure my mom suffered from some form; she would always have all these stacks of newspapers around and things. but she was not as messy and that sort of thing as i was, but i was always just sort of lazy. lazy is the prime reason that im this way, and secondarily, i look at all these piles, and like i said, i get kind of scared and then i dont want to deal with it, and ill put it off, and pretty soon ive done nothing for months, you know, that sort of thing.

Call: so you mentioned being scared. could you elaborate more on what scares you about these piles of things that youve accumulated over time?
Response: i dont know, just having to start going through them and i dont know that its boring, but its really abhorrent to me. i dont know why i dont want to deal with it, and you know, itd be so much easier if i either say folded clothes and put them away or dealt with things immediately after getting them or putting them in their place, but then theres so many things too that come in that pile up and you know, i kind of spend a lot of time in the front room, so everything kind of winds up in the front room.

Call: right, right. its always nice to have someone to help you.
Response: yeah, like this 1-800 got junk? commercials look really appealing.

Call: what kind of items do you collect?
Response: well lately ive been buying some books, and then like i said, some tech equipment. lets see well obviously ive been buying a lot of stuff on amazon for the house. weve been collecting toilet paper.

Call: right, the covid crisis definitely increases my online shopping, for sure.
Response: oh for sure, and hoarding too!

Call: have you ever gone to a professional to help with this behavior?
Response: no.

Call: okay, so you mentioned that sometimes your family members get a little bit upset. what are some of the things that they want you to do other than cleaning up persay? do they get upset when you buy new things or.
Response: oh yeah, husband especially gets upset, but then mostly its been stuff for the house, so he cant get upset with this!

Call: have you ever had conflicts with other people close to you that arent family members, like landlords or other people?
Response: oh no, thank god. no, that hasnt been a problem. its been family because most of it is, well, in the home is cluttered.

Call: right. so speaking of your home, the next section of questions i have is about your space and your living area, and how you see your home. can you describe where you live now?
Response: well i live in a single family home. i live with my husband and one of my adult daughters. its in a suburb and oh go ahead..

Call: no, no, no, i was just going to ask, what is the space like?
Response: its a small home. its got about 900 square feet, and technically there are three bedrooms. theyre very small and, you know, theres a lot of stuff in this house, and some of it is is co-collected by my husband or theres other things, and im not responsible for that room right now, although some of it is my stuff.

Call: so he keeps stuff in there too, its not just you.
Response: he does. yeah, and i have to say, he you know we bought one of these electric fireplaces sort of units, and oh this is nice, and he happens to work at a home improvement store, so he bought another one that were not using now, and he stuffed it in my daughters bedroom. and then, you know, we were talking about needing a fan so we bought an indoor air conditioning unit, not just a fan, which got stuffed in my daughters bedroom, unopened. and we also have, he picked up where he works, an actual window air conditioning unit which is sitting here in the front room. so, some of this clutter is his! but most of its mine because i just turn my crap on top of it. so, yeah, theres some times, like the front room here is the most cluttered, and its mostly my stuff, and its like clothes sitting on top of boxes, you know, one of which is.

Call: *phone call hangs up*
Response: im sorry! i didnt know what happened!

Call: i think the call dropped or something! i think it dropped when you were saying about clothes being piled up on top of boxes and such.
Response: yes, thats right, that was most of it, yes, and the boxes of both air conditioners are here, and opened and unopened boxes of stuff. and camping equipment and a wheelchair and other stuff.

Call: okay, so.. oh is that your dog?
Response: sorry.

Call: oh thats okay, i have little dogs barking all the time too. so, what would you like your home to look like?
Response: well, i would like it to be at least uncluttered so that people can sit on the couches or use the bed that we have here in the front room.

Call: right, so just a little less cluttered so that you could entertain more?
Response: yeah, because its embarrassing for both my husband and me. we never have people here because its just cluttered and no place to sit and well im not great at housekeeping either.

Call: how important are your things for you to feel at home in your space?
Response: you know, i feel good that i have the things that i do, and you know, im trying not to get more things. you know, its nice that i have them, i dont you know, the only things that worry me may be perhaps like a fire or something like that.

Call: are there things that you keep that have sentimental value or?
Response: yeah, a lot of it is sentimental value like, well various items and stuff that ive had from my youth or stuff that was handed down to me or things that i collect like, you know, say i like led zeppelin so i collected all the.. he put out a new album several years ago, so i collected all that, and i have a few books, and or say other books that i have about cartooning or disney or something like that.

Call: right, and which things are most important to you?
Response: well, photographs first of all; family photographs. the art in files and things that ive done all through the years like the stuff on my computer. and my phone! and then stuff that you cant really replace like stuff youve been given or that kind of stuff, or stuff youve collected that is hard to replace, certain t shirts or something like that.

Call: alright so irreplaceable items, family photos, those are what you hold close.
Response: yeah.

Call: okay, and are there parts of your home that you dont use? i know that youve mentioned that front room that you have or are there parts of your home that arent used in the way that theyre supposed to be used?
Response: well for sure the front room isnt used the way its supposed to be used, but i use it a lot. im out here a lot. not really.

Call: like the kitchen is used for cooking, the bathtub, and stuff like that
Response: yeah, all that stuff is used, yeah. its not cluttered so much that the kitchen is pretty okay. its a little cluttered, but its fully usable and so is the bathroom. yeah, its mostly the front room here.

Call: yeah, so one room of just clutter then.
Response: yeah.

Call: okay, so now this section of questions is about how you value your possessions. so i know that you mentioned that your pictures and your files are what you hold most dear, but when you think about all of your possessions, what makes them valuable to you?
Response: mostly either the things that you cant replace or oh yeah the files are included because thats all years and years and years of work which is like artwork or things that i value. yeah, so the most difficult ones are, you know, your photos which are family things, which you cant just buy; you cant replace them.

Call: irreplaceable memories.
Response: yeah.

Call: right, so what do you consider trash? i know you mentioned getting rid of things is hard for you, but what type of items do you discard?
Response: a lot of old papers, which i generally have to do that every year for income taxes, going through papers and stuff. and thats not as hard as going through things like piles of clothes. so what i try to trash is stuff thats old, meaning that you cant use it anymore, things that im not using anymore. and not everything gets trashed because some things we give to, like theres a local goodwill type of thing, you know, so if theres like clothes or other things that people can use, we gather those together periodically and bring those to that local place. but otherwise its paperwork, clothes that im not using or dont fit

Call: okay. 2
Response: theres a lot of potential trash here too, that im not going through.

Call: well aside from the people in it and my puppy dog.. precious, the most precious item in my house just one?!
Response: if you can choose one. 2

Call: just the things that capture the memories.
do you think you have too much stuff? i know that you mentioned the clutter, its a lot, but how do you know you have too much stuff?
Response: well because kind of the house is overflowing with it, like, you know, even in terms of  incoherent closet, and i hate going through that, but i guess im going to have to go through that again too because its like all these old medicines and things, but anyway theres not even enough room to put towels in there and sheets, and sometimes they overflow out here and

Call: thats how you know you have too much stuff.
Response: yes.

Call: okay. so now im just going to ask you a couple questions about distinguishing hoarding disorder. what do you think are the most important differences between what is considered normal saving behavior, such as collecting, and hoarding disorder?
Response: well collecting is more of an organized activity, where you know everything you have, you kind of may have lists of it, and you store them together in an orderly fashion.

Call: okay, so its just more orderly, you know what you have.
okay, so organization is definitely a big thing.

right, so i know i asked you how you can tell if someone has hoarding disorder in the beginning. so you mentioned that its messy and they have trouble getting rid of things, so how is that the same or different from your behavior?
Response: i think its the same. i mean, i have trouble getting rid of things for whatever reason, and its a big mess, and its very apparent, and its in the way of, you know, life here, and its pissing people off.

Call: thank you!
Response: perhaps, i mean i carry like a little fanny pack as my purse, and its usually stuffed. although, i dont have a problem emptying out the garbage and that sort of stuff periodically from it. so i dont know if you could infer that if somebody has you know a purse stuffed with stuff i dont know!

Call: i dont know either, but i know its a females prerogative to carry a purse, so.
Response: you would think that a person who has hoarding disorder, their car would be disorganized. its full of trash and all this stuff.

Call: okay, so their car could be a way to tip someone off that someone may have hoarding disorder.
Response: it could be, but if you look at my car, its fine. i dont keep crap in it that shouldn't be there, and i dont pile trash in there either, so.

Call: okay, so where do you get your information about hoarding disorder?
Response: maybe online or i like to watch a lot of medical or such type programs on tv.

Call: can you give me a couple of examples of these shows that you watch?
Response: well i dont watch, maybe because its painful! theres this show i think called hoarding or the hoarders or something like that.

Call: right, i think ive heard of that one.
Response: yeah, and ive watched one or two of those, and, you know, you would think im a hoarder from watching that. although, we can mostly  incoherent in this one room!

Call: so would you say compared to the extreme cases on those shows, would you have less clutter than them?
Response: yes.

Call: okay, and what do you think about when you hear the words hoarding disorder?
Response: i think, you know, somebody who has a uh. well for a lack of a better term, mental problem, and, you know i dont know, because these people are hanging on to things because they cant get rid of them, and mine is more like im too lazy to go through and get rid of stuff. i dont generally have a problem disposing of things or getting rid of things, unless its something that, you know, either has memories or its something that im collecting. yeah so, i dont know if im just lazy and dont want to do it.. i dont know!

Call: okay, so in our last section, i just have a couple more questions for you. do your problems with clutter upset you?
Response: yeah. it upsets me, you know, because we cant really have people in here to have like a dinner party or anything. theres no room. it upsets my family. it gets in the way of everything, you know, it always pisses my husband off, and he gets pissed off at enough things, youd think i'd be able to control this to where its one less thing hed be pissed about.

Call: right, so you mentioned that it gets in the way of everything, so would you say it gets in the way of your daily life?
Response: not so much, you know, if we vacuum around it, but you know, its in the way because the room cannot be used the way its supposed to be used. theres not enough room in it with all the clutter in it on top of things, and it just looks disorganized and messy and, you know, you dont really want to have visitors or friends come over. i look at other peoples houses and theyre all clean and lovely and lots of space and no problems. and i look at my front room and it's embarrassing! and it looks like im, for lack of a better word, trailer trash or something. yeah it is a better word! my daughters here!

Call: so could you describe a time where your clutter got in the way of something you really wanted? i know you mentioned that its difficult to entertain and have people over because its embarrassing to you.
Response: well more importantly than being embarrassing, the way that i couldnt house my daughter here the way that would be best for everyone was really impacting the lives of everyone else in this house, so that was a big impact for about a week here.

Call: so definitely it gets in the way of your family time.
Response: and just being an eyesore, you know, the fact that my husband cant stand it. its just all around bad.

Call: okay, and has your clutter ever impacted your work?
Response: yeah, because, you know, my work space is kind of papers all over the place, and theyve continually told me, many times, to keep my workspace organized and clean. and it's like, but i know where everything is here! but i couldve cleaned it up more, i didnt need all those papers around at all times.

Call: so would you be upset if you hid to get rid of some of your items?
Response: not general items. if its stuff that ive collected or have sentimental attachment to i would be upset.

Call: so if its just something lying around the house that doesnt have any emotional attachment, then you would be okay getting rid of it?
Response: yeah.

Call: okay, so that was actually my last question for you. so now im just going to ask you a couple of demographic questions just so we have that. so my first one is; gender identity?
Response: female.

Call: your sex assigned at birth?
Response: female

Call: your race?
Response: caucasian

Call: ethnicity? do you identify as hispanic or latino?
Response: no, i identify as jewish actually. well actually, ethnically, im 99.7!

Call: okay, and general household income? you can give me a range.
okay and your geographic region?
Response: west.

Call: and your highest level of education?
Response: aa degree, associates degree.

Call: right, and would you prefer an electronic amazon gift card by email or physical gift card? i do have to say that if you do choose a physical gift card, it could take up to 3 to 4 weeks to get to you because of covid.
Response: right, email gift card is fine.

Call: and one of the things that i wonder about is is it a delusional disorder, like--
Response: it's very interesting you bring that up because i was just this morning at a meeting at the association of prosecuting attorneys working with a judge who i've worked with on a number of hoarding cases, and she just had a case of a client who was charged with animal hoarding, i forget all the details but i believe it was quite a few dogs--more than 30--but he was found not competent based on a delusion.

Call: do you think that that's fair?
Response: i think it shows great insight, it shows a much higher level of understanding i think of the thought processes of a hoarder than i normally see from clinicians who don't really recognize what's going on.

Call: one is insight into the actual physical situation and how bad it is, and the other is insight into the way that it could be interfering with one's life and kind of separating those out.
Response: that's absolutely right, and usually one of the things we see in probably i think in about 25% of the animal hoarding cases is we do have an impact on others in their care, either dependent adults or children.

Call: and i guess in cases of animal hoarding, i remember you talking about in our last conversation that sometimes people will actually have social networks or people who are kind of supporting them in their behavior, and how does that work with this kind of delusional almost aspect of...does it become a shared delusion?
Response: almost a shared delusion, like we've had--in the case of our rescue hoarders, which are our most common large-scale hoarding situations, so people who at least present themselves or describe themselves as rescuers and sometimes actually formerly have a non-profit status and claim to be a rescue organization, and when they do come in conflict with the law or are charged with animal cruelty, many of the enablers or people who have assisted them will show up at their hearings and their trials and will also have the same level of denial.

Call: do you have any knowledge of how that gets built?
Response: well usually these are fellow hoarders.

Call: so it almost appears to be a community in some cases?
Response: well, and that's something that's also i think unique to animal hoarders.

Call: can you ever think of a case of an animal hoarder who gained a degree of insight over time, or who came to understand their behavior differently?
Response: i've heard of one or two people who have particularly, if they have other complicating factors like other anxiety disorders or depression, i've heard of a few hospitalized hoarders who after some pharmacological interventions briefly seemed to show some insight like, "why is it i have so many animals?" and yet, they relapsed.

Call: are they different expressions of the same impulse, or are they totally different?
Response: they're not totally different, but there are different things--and there is some literature, you know randy frost has written some stuff on the distinction between the two.

Call: so there's high comorbidity of depression or with object hoarding often.
Response: right, right, we certainly do see a number of different potential co-morbidities.

Call: so they kind of personify or over-empathize with objects.
Response: right, whereas actually letting an animal go is actually killing it or potentially killing it, the greatest anxiety a lot of the animal hoarders have is their animals will be taken away and euthanized, and the reality is it becomes almost a self-fulfilling prophesy because the animals deteriorate.

Call: it does sound like you see them as different kinds of the same thing, or at least of existing on a spectrum.
Response: right, right, the depth of potential attachment to an animal is obviously much stronger, and then in terms of being the public health aspect as i said, you know, animals pee and poor and reproduce and die, which your toasters don't.

Call: so perhaps the reason we could speculate--and cut me off if you think that this is wrong--but we could speculate that maybe part of the reason that the rate of recidivism tends to be so high with animal hoarding and insight tends to be so low, while it is in object hoarding i think it's uniquely low in animal hoarding, could perhaps be because it requires so much more investment in terms of keeping the animals, so much more investment in the beliefs about the animals and also the animals kind of give back more than objects.
Response: yeah the animals give back more and in terms of the emotional investment, again i wasn't necessarily trained or all that familiar with self-psychology, i've talked to a number of people that that's their main focus, but i certainly see it as--and when we teach responders in how to deal with animal hoarders, we have to respect the fact that this is the core of their being.

Call: so, maybe some degree of ownership of animals helps to kind of mitigate that distress that they experience and also helps--go ahead.
Response: we don't have data to necessarily support that, it makes sense but if often puts us into conflict with sometimes the animal advocates say, "this person did horrible things to animals and they should never be allowed to have any animals again."

Call: or have you seen them in treatment?
Response: a few, and it's still rare that you get compliance and part of the problem too is that if the situation is really quite severe, so they've been unable to provide for the animal's medical needs and spay/neuter needs and proper diet and so on, often they're on public assistance or medicare or whatever and often there are limits to what public systems will provide in terms of psychological assessment, maybe 8-12 visits, well that's not enough.

Call: that seems to be something that's a little bit different than with object hoarding is, while there's these dsm-v criteria that are applied that are applied to individuals to see if they are individuals with hoarding disorder, but it seems that process of diagnosis happens quite infrequently with animal hoarding, it tends to be a situation where there either is or is not legal intervention necessary and that's as far as it goes.
Response: did i send you, or i can send you if you don't have it the article that NAME and i wrote on case outcomes in--

Call: no you didn't but i would love it, yeah
Response: do you have it?

Call: no, i can look it up though but i would love it if you could send it to me, i spoke to NAME.
Response: yeah i definitely will send it to you, it's now probably we really should revisit that because obviously we're much farther down the road, i should talk to NAME about re-doing it, it was a little difficult to put together obviously as a follow up.

Call: well it sounds like maybe it's moving in the same direction as object hoarding disorder, maybe like five or ten years ago where it's starting to be moved form this kind of like marginalized, criminalized behavior-oriented, punishment-oriented thinking towards more mental illness treatment-oriented thinking and so perhaps there will be more.
Response: as a big difference though in object hoarding, let's say you have really messy hoarding situations, at worst that's usually going to be a civil intervention, if law gets involved it's going to be violations or code violations or so-on, it's not a criminal case; whereas with animal hoarding, if animals are dying that's criminal and that's the big difference.

Call: do you think that hoarding disorder or that animal hoarding is going to be brought out or should be brought out as an official sub-type with it's own diagnostic criteria in the dsm?
Response: you know, i don't think--it's an interesting question because as a practical measure in how we respond it clearly is different, it requires different resources to address in terms of the underlying psychology, there probably are differences because of the reciprocal nature of the attachment to the animals as opposed to objects, whether or not that is different enough to make it a totally different diagnosis i don't know.

Call: and that there aren't that many clinical experts anyway and you wouldn't find somebody who's an expert in the treatment of animal hoarding disorder in any case, this doesn't exist.
Response: exactly, right and randy frost doesn't want any more referrals LAUGHS.

Call: we talked in the beginning of the interview about the reasons that people give for keeping their animals or for hoarding animals, and i wonder if in your mind those reasons are actually what is driving their behavior, or are those reasons kind of a post-hoc justification for what is a kind of fundamental underlying need to--?
Response: yeah, i think that's closer to the reality partly because of the actual situation.

Call: is it something that the person has been at risk for their whole life even when they're children, or is it something that develops abruptly at a certain age?
Response: i think it seems to be, the literature seems to be moving in the direction that there are pre-dispositions that often show up in adolescents or even the twenties seem to become perhaps solidified a bit by mid thirties and obviously increases with age, and one of the things we haven't talked about is also as with collecting and object hoarding and so on, there is a spectrum to where you know everybody has some degree of clutter, everybody collects some things or other and everybody sometimes sees uniqueness in some of the stuff they have that other people might not see.

Call: well so that's a question because you're not, so with object hoarding as well there is this sense even among clinicians of the best way to know if somebody is a hoarder is to look at how much stuff they have, and it's striking to me that there really aren't other disorders in general where you would diagnose a person by looking at something external to them, how much they've accumulated and you point out the example of the women with the lhasa apso where you know, with object hoarding if you have a big enough house you will never fit the criteria for object hoarding, because you have enough space that it's never gonna get in the way of your--
Response: right, right,

Call: so that for me raises the question of you know, is this a disorder only a disorder when it starts to interfere with the person's life?
Response: exactly--well, and that's practically if we get back to my original statement is where this becomes recognized is if it is interfering with your activities of daily living.

Call: so then that's the question, is a disorder a thought or is a disorder a behavior?
Response: i think...well it's a disorder of thought that often intrudes upon a behavior, although there can be factors that minimize the impact of the behavior or exacerbate the behavior.

Call: let me get--i would like to talk about it with you at the end of the interview so that i can get your, your kind of off the cuff impressions first.
Response: oh right, good point.

Call: but no, i would love to hear your thoughts about results because you know we're nearing 30 interviews, and these are interviews really with people who are the experts of all experts on this disorder, the group that we would hope would have the most consistent responses.
Response: right, that's what's kind of worrying but, like you said, we'll talk about that at the end.

Call: yeah.
Response: but yeah, you would hope that the 30 of us would have come to an agreement.

Call: yeah, so there is agreement on some topics, but there's still disagreement on some aspects so, i think it's worthwhile to know about that.
Response: okay.

Call: now i'd like to move more into the interview.
Response: yeah, that was fun.

Call: yeah, i mean it's always interesting particularly to see, at least we've just been interviewing clinicians, but the list that is most different i think is the underlying causes, and it really depends on people's backgrounds, the things that might contribute to hoarding disorder, which is probably not a surprise to you.
Response: yeah.

Call: and that's just a general trend, people have always seemed to have a mix, but the order that they put them in i think will be very interesting to breakdown based on different kinds of clinicians and researchers, how they think about it.
Response: yeah, cuz unfortunately all these things are so messy, there's gonna be an interaction of all those things, and i didn't mention genetics but i do think that creates a backdrop when these things happen.

Call: so like when somebody is exhibiting this behavior, is it because they have a problem with their thought process where they truly believe that, you know, they're going to screw up the environment or they're gonna need it later, or is it that they're saving it and then when you ask them, "why do you saved this?" they come up with a with a reason that seems to make sense to them why they would save it, but it's really behavioral driven?
Response: right, that's a really good question and i think that we need more research to iron out, but the other thing i think about that sometimes is that it can be some central problem that's driving lot's of different things in their lives.

Call: another interesting thing that has happened with this list, i gave you the list of "how would you know that somebody has hoarding disorder?" and some clinicians take it the way you did where it was like, "how would i diagnose a person and know if they came in my office?" but some clinicians have started to generate these lists, and i think that they're just interpreting the question differently, i don't think that this is a difference in understanding, but it's very interesting to me nonetheless, they give a list of what a person with hoarding disorder would look like, like what are some other characteristics of that person apart from their hoarding.
Response: like sitting in the waiting room without talking to them, yeah that did kind of cross my mind a little, but you're right i didn't go that direction.

Call: so if you were to paint me a picture of a typical hoarding patient, what would they look like?
Response: yeah, i would say more quirky and eccentric looking, more disheveled, more chaotic looking, sometimes more socially awkward, but some people with hoarding are really socially engaging and charming, but other people just present as a little bit more socially awkward.

Call: they'll say like a person who talks a lot and talks kind of tangentially and seems like they have trouble zeroing in on the topic of conversation sometimes, like you said, very frazzled, they tend to be kind of like get overly emotionally empathetic or overly involved in other people's lives and business and drama, they are always late for everything, they always have a ton of stuff with them everywhere they go, they are very disorganized in every aspect of their life, so they can't manage their calendar, stuff like that.
Response: yeah, and i guess the positive aspect of that that sometimes goes along with it is they do some--not everyone, but again as a stereotype, really interested in things and kind of creative.

Call: it's interesting too, and i don't know if this is just because the people i've interviewed generally like all of their clients, but i feel like experts in hoarding disorder, as you just did, often go out of their way to say like, "actually there's really nice things about these people as well."
Response: i hope it's not because we all perceive there to be a stigma against it.

Call: yeah, maybe, i don't know i just--
Response: which i think there is.

Call: yeah, there definitely is, but i've definitely had the experience of clinicians often times kind of pointing out the creative and interesting aspect of people with hoarding disorder.
Response: yeah, oh good.

Call: yeah, anyway,
Response: i mean that's probably the reason some of us have chosen to work with it as well.

Call: so, just to kind of dive into the rest of our interview script, if you wouldn't mind just giving me like a two minute overview of your experience in terms of this disorder and, you know, if you see patients clinically, if you're mostly involved with research.
Response: okay, so, starting in graduate school i was running hoarding treatment groups supervised by NAME and then decided to do that as my phd research and from that time on, have done a series of studies over the last two decades.

Call: okay, so just to get into kind of talking about the diagnostic criteria now, for you, what do you think are the most important differences between the spectrum of normal saving behavior, such as perhaps extreme collecting, and hoarding disorder?
Response: i mean i always fall back on like the dsm interference and distress, but i think that's probably a little bit of a banal answer or not exactly what you're looking for.

Call: so, a person who has an extensive like cuckoo clock collection that fills their home would still fit the criteria.
Response: cuckoo clocks, that might be harder to fit the criteria because you could possibly be a connoisseur and it sounds less-likely that it could dominate your living space completely, but i have seen people that, for example, primarily collect bikes, but they're old and broken bikes, and they do fill up their homes, their garage, their living space, their bedrooms, and they're not organized, they're not high value, and yes it's one item, but it is a problem.

Call: so, the kind of indiscriminate nature of the saving is not a firm diagnostic criteria, but it does tend to be less discriminant?
Response: um, i guess i would say, cuz even the bike scenario, that it is still indiscriminate.

Call: the really extreme example is a, i read an article in the newspaper about a couple who died whose home was absolutely impassable and was filled to the brim with their art collection, and their art collection turned out to be valued at millions and millions of dollars, they were actually art collectors and they had a lot of knowledge, you know, they had picassos and matisse, and all kinds of stuff, but completely not on display, filling their home, making their rooms jam-packed, and they knew where the stuff was and they knew what they had but it was not organized.
Response: that's a great extreme example, what did people do with that one?

Call: yeah,
Response: are you just an art collector with not enough space?

Call: sure, yeah, i mean--
Response: yeah, they're still disorganized about it, they're still chaotic about it, they're still letting it get in the way of their functioning.

Call: i mean, how would you make that call?
Response: how i would make that call is i would probably need to go into their home and see what's happening.

Call: my understanding from the newspaper article that i read was that it was like every square inch of their home was jam-packed, but like i wasn't there so i don't know.
Response: so, they really were kind of having to squish their way through.

Call: i mean, where this is reflected in the dsm-v is the difficulty discarding or parting with possessions regardless of their actual value, and i guess i'm wondering like, is the inability to properly evaluate or value items a necessary part of the disorder or not?
Response: right, and i guess if you just go back to our general psychiatric classification system and try and step back from hoarding per se, it's still a disorder if they're not functioning in their home.

Call: okay, can you think of an example of a specific case or cases where you personally had trouble making diagnostic decisions, either whether it was true hoarding or subclinical hoarding, or whether it was hoarding or something else.
Response: yeah, where that's why i kind of like your art example because in reality, i feel like that rarely happens.

Call: so, along those lines kind of how do you make the distinction between a person, or do you find it difficult to distinguish between a person who has a primary diagnosis or hoarding disorder versus a primary diagnosis of depression, which is causing them to not be able to throw stuff out because they're too depressed to get up and do it?
Response: yeah, so my key question with that one is, "okay, if i were to come over tomorrow and throw things away to help you clear out your house, how would you feel?" and a person with depression is usually like, "that would be great, please do that."

Call: so, somebody who doesn't throw stuff away because they're worried about losing something that they might need, or they're really fearful of kind of germs and they don't want to touch their stuff to throw it out?
Response: yeah, i think that in that latter case with the germs, you're able to figure that out pretty quickly.

Call: do you think that someone can have both obsessive compulsive disorder and hoarding as separate things?
Response: yes, i have seen people who have both, yeah.

Call: do you feel like it's common for people to have both, or it's pretty unusual?
Response: i'd say it's not that common.

Call: and i guess, this again i'm asking you to kind of speculate, but do you feel like they have comorbid depression because perhaps those are genetically related, or do you feel like they have comorbid depression because of the impact that hoarding disorder is having on their life?
Response: definitely more the former, they have underlying environmental genetic vulnerability to emotional disorders.

Call: okay, do you believe that, or have you seen cases of subclinical hoarding disorder?
Response: rarely, sometimes, sometimes the young people will do some testing with undergraduates and we see like, "oh dear, this could be hoarding one day."

Call: well so, that brings me to a question that i was going to ask you later but i can ask now, it said: as i'm sure you're aware, the literature shows that hoarding disorder's more common in elderly people, and i guess what i'm wondering is do you see that as being kind of like... it is progressive?
Response: an artifact.

Call: so like has the impulse gotten worse over their lifespan, or has it just gotten to the point in older people where they can no longer control it, also because of cognitive or mobility issues?
Response: i think both of those things and an artifact of the way that we do research and when people finally develop insight motivation.

Call: is there anything that sticks out to you,, like in reflecting on those criteria as--?
Response: honestly, no. i mean, i guess prior to this conversation i thought they seemed reasonably clear and solid and i didn't have any real concerns about being able to apply them.

Call: okay, and i guess like, just to take a step back and clarify, the purpose of this study was never to critique the dsm-v criteria, and it may be that this is the best criteria that there could be, i mean like there may just be--
Response: oh yeah, i wasn't implying that you're critiquing it, i just think it's interesting that people are applying it differently, and that hasn't really occurred to me.

Call: do you get them to describe their space, do you look at photographs of their space?
Response: yeah, ideally both.

Call: right, kind of to take that one step further, how would you use this criteria in like an adolescent or a child who's space is being actively managed and controlled by somebody else?
Response: yeah, i find that really tricky and, to be fair, i don't actually assess or diagnose many kids with hoarding, but it is something that encouraged me and it has happened more with our uni students, which is something that i do deal with regularly, is how do you figure out what would happen if the external constraints were removed?

Call: how would you make that call?
Response: yeah, i think i would still be going back to conflict in distress in that case.

Call: and the clinician that we talked to--
Response: and pay someone to organize it, wow that's another idea too.

Call: because the person didn't meet the clutter criteria and didn't experience distresses, so.
Response: painful

Call: and the clinician was perplexed because if they were physical--
Response: yeah, i think in that one i would get kind of pragmatic, and maybe with the millionaire as well, in the sense that we have limited clinical resources and treatment resources so, if they person is not presenting to treatment, if it's just a hypothetical thought experiment, i would not be bothering to diagnose them with hoarding disorder.

Call: and if you were to take a parallel example with ocd, it's not as though if someone has like a hand washing obsession, that we ask to see their hands to say like, "oh, have you washed your hands enough to qualify as ocd, are you losing skin?" you know, like the ideation and the belief and the behavior is enough, we don't really look at the consequences of the behavior in that was.
Response: yeah, i absolutely get that, but on the other hand, the pragmatic side of me and the side that knows that we're also up against a world that possibly rightfully pushes back against the idea of overpatholagizing everything and making everything into a disorder and a diagnosis, you know, there's all this kind of variation in how much stuff we want or have, and we just need to leave that alone and not be the psychiatrist fascists who get in there and diagnose everyone and create problems where there are none.

Call: i definitely agree, i don't know that there's a--
Response: it's such a tricky one.

Call: so, with that person, where's the distress?
Response: i guess, for me, i allow it to be the distress that brought them into treatment, which may not be--you're absolutely right--distress about the stuff they have, but distress about the issues that have resulted from it.

Call: so, would that person have hoarding disorder?
Response: um, it would, it would still fit criteria for me.

Call: is that the intended use for that person?
Response: yeah, i mean i guess at that point i'm willing to let it not be hoarding.

Call: if you're excluding people who are not experiencing distress, then your really severe hoarders are never--
Response: yeah, excellent point.

Call: which do you kind of experience with patients most?
Response: i'm sorry, could you just go through them one more time for me?

Call: defensiveness, which is kind of related to not acknowledging it because they're worried about losing their things; and indifference, so saying, "i know that this space is unacceptable by most people's standards, but i don't care and i'm happy with it."
Response: okay, so are you asking which is the most common or which is the hardest to deal with?

Call: all four of those or are there one or two that jump out at you as being, kind of, at the root of the problem?
Response: i guess i kind of think of all of them, except for maybe--well, yeah i think of all of them to some extent.

Call: or--
Response: that's why i don't fully buy the illness one.

Call: people talk about animal hoarding as being like truly on the delusional spectrum, where they really believe that they're saving these animals that are dying on the floor.
Response: truly horrific, yeah, the things that they don't see, that they really truly believe that they love these animals and that these animals are suffering and that they can't see it is just a horrific combination.

Call: if this distress criteria is a necessary component to the diagnosis of hoarding disorder, but at the same time we're saying that the disorder itself may have a delusional component whereby they truly can't see the things that would be distressing to them, how do we make the diagnosis?
Response: what about my weasel strategy of they might not be distressed because of the animal or the items, but they are distressed because people are threatening to take their animals away or people are yelling at them about their clutter.

Call: it's kind of like a side effect, you know like, they save stuff as a side effect of having the behavior or the beliefs.
Response: so, if you strip that away i mean i think these are all important, interesting questions, i'm just thinking like okay if you strip those things away, everything that is external is no longer.

Call: something along those lines, it would have to be very--because you know, and again, i'm not saying that that would be better, it would definitely be way harder to use, but when you think about like--
Response: it's an important conversation, it reminds me a little bit, i guess you would argue this is still central to the person, if you removed all the weight criteria from anorexia and said like there's so many young women and men and people who just constantly obsessively worry about their weight and dieting and whatever, but they're normal weight or slightly overweight.

Call: you know, that's where you get into research--
Response: yeah, i mean i think it's a fantastic point.

Call: yeah, i mean, i think the--
Response: i think it'd be a really cool debate though; i think it's such an interesting point your raising would be is this really worth considering?

Call: so the reasons that they give kind of give away a little bit--
Response: post hoc justifications

Call: and if so, is that different in australia?
Response: absolutely, and what the person thinks is more of a justification.

Call: granted, that's a very small sample size, but it's 10 episodes a season and there's two people per episode, so 20 hoarders a year for 10 years, just to see how it shifts.
Response: wow, that is such a great idea.

Call: we'll see how it goes.
Response: i think people have done interesting stigma stuff, NAME i think is doing it, i can't pronounce his last name correctly but showing people's attitudes, this is a different question but, pre- and post- watching the show, "hoarders" and how it affects their feelings of stigma, but i think using that show over time is also really interesting to see reasons for saving, how they've changed.

Call: we'll see how it goes.
Response: isn't there a british hoarding show as well as an american one?

Call: but anyway, we'll see what happens.
Response: yeah, i love it.

Call: and just to kind of get us started in talking about your experiences and your knowledge of this topic, uhm if you wouldnt mind just giving us a brief background related to how you became involved with hoarding disorder and what your professional interactions with hoarders are.
Response: ok.

Call: how did you come to work at the center?
Response: uh, so im a nurse and a marriage and family therapist.

Call: do you see patients clinically?
Response: yeah, now my work with hoarders is mostly clinical, not research based.

Call: and how long has it been that youve worked with these patients specifically?
Response: oh my gosh, probably since the early 90s.

Call: yeah, so uh the next question that we want to ask you is if you can talk to us about what the most important differences are between normal saving behavior, like collecting perhaps, and hoarding disorder?
Response: i think people who save things as a collection are usually able to take care of their collection.

Call: what do they look like?
Response: uhm, gosh.

Call: no not at all-
Response: uh, usually not married.

Call: you know, racially, in terms of ses, rural versus urban?
Response: economically, i would say lower economic class.

Call: and how you went about making that distinction?
Response: huh i cant think of many cases where it was difficult to diagnose because of- there was subclinical.

Call: how did that manifest in the patients that youll see with deficits?
Response: very disorganized, unable to make decisions, unable to prioritize, difficulty initiating a task, difficulty completing tasks-- even the most mundane, banal, simple tasks, they typically struggle with.

Call: do you feel like its sometimes difficult to make a clinical diagnosis of hoarding disorder in terms of other, either concomitant mental health problems that the person might have or because they might look similar to obsessive compulsive disorder and other mental health disorders?
Response: no, i mean, im kind of used to doing pretty thorough and pretty extensive evaluations.

Call: and youve used these criteria with the intent of diagnosing an individual with hoarding disorder, correct?
Response: right.

Call: and so, we were kind of wondering about the process of evaluation for hoarding disorder and how you look at, you know, the possessions that a person has accumulated and determine value, and whether its appropriate or not.
Response: mhm.

Call: and whats the response of a typical patient with hoarding disorder to that question?
Response: its important, its valuable, ill need it later

Call: INAUDIBLE so they can separate it from obsessive compulsive disorder where they might be more afraid that there will be some consequences or uhm is that why the purpose of that question?
Response: i think yes, and, you know, some people with obsessive compulsive disorder might throw things away, but theyre going to save something like-- you know they throw it away because its contaminated, or they might say theyre going to keep it because they cant touch it because its contaminated, or they keep it because their rituals prevent them touching it- like they cant take the trash out because they cant touch the trash.

Call: and that, for you, is kind of very a key distinguishing factor for distinguishing hoarding from obsessive compulsive disorder INAUDIBLE.
Response: right!

Call: or does it just depend on the patient?
Response: i think it very much depends on the patient.

Call: so there can be kind of a range.
Response: yeah, and it being thought of as creative and individual.

Call: and how do you kind of grapple with those issues in making a diagnosis?
Response: uhm, sorry the lines very fuzzy so im only catching bits of what youre saying.

Call: im sorry.
Response: no, thats okay.

Call: that would be, maybe addictive acquiring as opposed to hoarding?
Response: well we would have to rule out compulsive shopping, not that thats necessarily a dsm.

Call: but do you find that its-
Response: sorry go ahead.

Call: no, no, no. go ahead.
Response: no thats okay.

Call: or if you dont really feel like thats an issue?
Response: only a small- to a very small degree, because most people learn to live within their space.

Call: or is that also not something that really comes up?
Response: uhm it doesnt actually come up that much.

Call: mhm, so they seem to want to use it for whatever its intended purpose is, but they are not able to.
Response: yes.

Call: do you think that theres perhaps a way that hoarding disorder is related to this or could be an extension of this variance that surpasses the officially acceptable threshold?
Response: yeah, i think when it moves from being functional to non-functional.

Call: or do you find like thats not really a part of it, that its just as a byproduct of the saving?
Response: right.

Call: its just with their own space that they like that clutter.
Response: right, and i think its just that they like the security of feeling very- kind of like a cocoon, and theyll do that gesture where theyll wrap their arms around their body where theyre kind of enveloped, and that feels secure to them- they like that.

Call: and is it sometimes a problem for patients who perhaps have low insight into whats going on with them- that they dont admit to distress or they dont think they would be distressed when they throw things away?
Response: i think a lot of them- not all of them, but a lot of them- will articulate that they can throw it away or that they dont really need the stuff, that it annoys them, that they keep it.

Call: so, kind of to start this portion of the conversation, we wanted to ask you, how do you define insight?
Response: uhm, usually when they can bring themselves into therapy and be aware that their hoarding is a problem, that its affecting their functioning, their ability to get things done, their relationship; when theyre aware they have trouble making decisions and following through on tasks.

Call: ok.
Response: i thinks that probably it.

Call: or is that a process that you take patients through?
Response: uhm, in the INAUDIBLE that i work in, most patients come in with some awareness that they have a problem, and they come in with a readiness to work on it, but thats the nature of the situations that i work in.

Call: ok. ok. are there any situations then, where youve had to help patients try to gain insight or go through that with them?
Response: i mean, weve definitely tried to improve on their insight, for sure.

Call: and how would you help a patient try to gain insight or move further in that path towards recognition of the problem and the relationship with the disorder?
Response: here we do a lot of education.

Call: ok. and so, when your patients will come in with a greater degree of insight, the ones that do, how do you think that they came to that insight or that understanding on their own, of their problem?
Response: i think its usually when, again, outside sources have been pushing them; family has kind of done an intervention or have been on their case, or a landlord has intervened and said something, or theres been a threat-

Call: some kind of external source
Response: usually some external source makes them sit up and think ok, this has gone on long enough, i have to do something about it

Call: do you see any of those more or less commonly?
Response: no, i think we see them all.

Call: and you see the other three about equally in the population that you work with?
Response: yes, yes, i think so.

Call: uhm so for the first question, how do you think your patients would respond to what do you think has caused you to have these behaviors, and do these behaviors have a psychiatric or underlying biological cause?
Response: right.

Call: so its theres of been a movement of people being more accepting that this is an actual disorder instead of just a problem of organization that they can cope with.
Response: yeah.

Call: the other one wed like you to think through how your patents would respond is how convinced are you that you need to keep these things or that some bad will come of discarding them? what do you think your patients would say in response to that?
Response: again, a range.

Call: is there also that element that something bad will come of discarding it or something bad will happen if they throw it away?
Response: oh probably.

Call: which do you think maybe came first, the urge to save or the reason for saving?
Response: gosh i never really thought of it like that.

Call: and i dont know, im just trying to think through the question with you.
Response: yeah, yeah.

Call: were not holding you to it, just kind of speculate, you know?
Response: yeah.

Call: and do you think that in any sense there are cultural forces that maybe associate value and self-worth with consumption and material possessions that might play a role in this disorder or do you think those are separating ideas?
Response: i mean not more than what weve talked about, with the cultural-- the identity of being frugal or creative or respectful of other people- you know, when people with hoarding keep things belonging to their deceased mother or their father, that kind of thing.

Call: the question was about that and also to kind of think about whether people might want to have more things because their value is associated with people who have a lot of things, but that sounds like youre saying its not related in quite that way.
Response: no, i think its more about their identity.

Call: yeah, we only have a couple questions left and i think we actually went through a decent number of them in our conversation earlier so in describing the patients that will come into your office for treatment, how long would they say that the hoarding behavior has been going on before you see them?
Response: its usually been decades.

Call: mhm.
Response: ok.so theyve become, kind of, newer hoarders.

Call: and you know, speaking of family, you said family and friends will often play a role in the patient coming in and identifying that something is wrong, or something is going on that needs treatment, and so just curious as to what relatives do you find are most often involved in that process with a patient?
Response: uh, in this program its usually extended family, not direct family.

Call: we really appreciate it.
Response: oh, you are very welcome.

Call: so, does anyone come to mind that you think we should definitely make sure we try to speak to for this project?
Response: you might have already talked to them because theyre already on the INAUDIBLE, but i would recommend NAME and NAME at UNIVERSITY

Call: so, thank you.
Response: ok, well good luck!

Call: thank you, take care.
Response: bye.

Call: im on the line with my colleague, name .
Response: hi name .

Call: nice to meet you.
Response: nice to meet you.

Call: we both read a lot of your work on hoarding disorder, so were really excited to talk to you today.
Response: well, its my pleasure.

Call: were still continuing to receive replies, so thank you again for that.
Response: good.

Call: do you have any questions about any of that?
Response: no, that sounds good.

Call: we just kind of wanted to start out wondering if you could give us your background relating to hoarding disorder to kind of start off.
Response: ok.

Call: ok. and can you tell us what your educational background is?
Response: i have a phd in clinical psychology.

Call: and so do you see patients with hoarding disorder clinically as well as conducting research?
Response: i only see patients clinically in connection with a research study or as, in a supervisory capacity at a supervised therapist, at a local mental health center that has an ocd center where we treat hoarding.

Call: so, with that little disclaimer, we would just like to kind of start off pretty broadly by asking you what the most important differences are between normal saving behavior, such as collecting, and hoarding disorder in your mind?
Response: ok.

Call: what are the demographics like?
Response: demographics for serious hoarding behavior, uh, someone who is in their fifties, mid- to late- fifties.

Call: something like that.
Response: yeah, not much difference for rural/urban.

Call: race and ethnicity?
Response: i dont think theres not much evidence out there about race and ethnicity.

Call: and kind of talk through that case or cases and how you made the distinction between something that was sub-clinical or something that was not true hoarding disorder and hoarding disorder patient.
Response: well theres two, two ways to think about that.

Call: and how do you make the distinction for those individuals?
Response: the distinctionyeah the way i make the distinction is the level distress associated with the management of possessions.

Call: so are there elements that you regard as difficult to apply or that you see different clinicians may apply differently?
Response: yeahi think, i think that one is certainly one thats a little difficult to apply because you got to make a judgement about interference and distress and if theres no clutter or little clutter in the living areas of the home.

Call: so
Response: yeah.

Call: the first one we have is persistent difficulty discarding or parting with possessions regardless of their actual value and were curious about you make the determination of value for individuals and their possessions and what makes the value judgement someone with hoarding disorders makes inappropriate?
Response: ok, yeah.

Call: go ahead.
Response: sure.

Call: and how you, how this criteria is meant just in terms of which of those ideas of value is meant by this criteria or all of them?
Response: all of them.

Call: or with
Response: with all objects.

Call: you know, you cant value everything as valuable.
Response: im not quite sure i follow what you said but i what my experience is that they value all objects and have great difficulty distinguishing the importance of possessions.

Call: so were curious about how you make the determination of how much stuff is too much, especially with things like home size and other people in the home may affect the degree of clutter in the space.
Response: yeah, yeah.

Call: what is the appropriate use?
Response: yeah, absolutely, absolutely.

Call: do you feel like hoarding disorder could just be an extension of this variance that surpasses socially acceptable thresholds?
Response: absolutely.

Call: so its interesting, and im wondering if you could talk a little bit more about how you see that in your patients or how, if you have examples of the way that people experience this differently.
Response: yeah.

Call: well how do you determine how much distress is normal or abnormal and how does that relate to potential insight issues when a patient denies having a problem and making that determination of distress?
Response: yeah.

Call: just making the determination in how much distress is normal or abnormal.
Response: oh yeah, okay.

Call: and so to kind of follow up on what you just said in terms of patients who may or may not realize the extent to which they are experiencing distress, i just wanted to start the conversation about insight by asking first how you would define insight in this context.
Response: my view of insight, i think, is that if we want to say whether or not someone has insight, we should use the more classical definition of insight, anosognosia  the understanding that i have a disorder where somethings wrong.

Call: thats a really important distinction.
Response: yeah.

Call: and that clinicians think that because the patient values a piece of paper they dont have insight
Response: right.

Call: but the patient actually is aware of the fact that that behavior represents itself as that novel behavior.
Response: it represents something that

Call: they do have insight.
Response: yeah.

Call: and does the idea of indifference kind of something that we heard from previous interviews is that when patients are indifferent, it can be difficult to distinguish hoarding disorder from disorders like depression where theyre simply indifferent to their surroundings or they dont throw things away because they dont care, and i wonder if you can talk through whether, kind of, insight.
Response: um im not quite sure i fully understood that.

Call: and kind of maybe to go along with that idea: when you meet a patient who is alleged to have very low insight, how do you help that patient try to gain insight or what do you say to them to help them to understand whats going on with their behavior as being problematic?
Response: well largely i approach it using a motivational interviewing approach; and the idea there is to begin where the patient is.

Call: how do patients come to this realization themselves sometimes or not?
Response: you mean the realization that i have a problem?

Call: the realization that they have a disorder that might need treatment.
Response: yeah.

Call: and that kind of arises just from interacting with people and recognizing the damage it does to your things that you value on your own?
Response: right.

Call: well i think id first like to hear about your availability name  for, if we would have some more questions for you today, would you be able to
Response: yeah.

Call: it that an okay way to proceed?
Response: yeah.

Call: um, excellent.
Response: so youll be in touch

Call: we really, really
Response: well set up another time?

Call: yeah we will.
Response: ok.

Call: we really appreciate your time and all of your work has been really great to read and this has been an extremely interesting conversation and i think that we both will look forward to continuing it when you have more time.
Response: alright.

Call: yeah, thank you very much.
Response: (part 2)

Call: good morning, NAME?
Response: yes, NAME?

Call: hi.
Response: alright, good.

Call: we really appreciate it.
Response: sure.

Call: and um, just to kind of reiterate, the goal is to eventually do patient interviews and hopefully have them take a look at these questions as well, and kind of be able to compare the answers that were getting from clinicians and what patients are actually telling us.
Response: ok.

Call: do these behaviors have a psychiatric or underlying biological cause? so, how do you think your patients would reply or respond to that?
Response: uh.

Call: do you think that there are things that would make a patient more likely to believe in the biological origin versus not?
Response: i think if they had recognized that in themselves and been trying to work on in and been unable to make progress, then i think theyre more likely to say its a biological cause, that theres something wrong with my brain.

Call: so, it seems like they need to have some insight in order to be doing the things to try and improve, that thats kind of tied into their understanding of it as being biological.
Response: i think so, yeah.

Call: yeah.
Response: but, what happens when you are when you have tried and failed at something?

Call: and, do you have you found or do you have any speculation as to which group would be easier to treat, of those two groups?
Response: well, i think the treatment starts in a different place.

Call: and in so its almost along a spectrum where considering it as a character trait may be kind of a little further behind the individual whos thinking of it as a biological disorder.
Response: right, right.

Call: can there be INAUDIBLE that they just need to INAUDIBLE.
Response: no, no, i think yeah, i think it can be looked at easily, the problem-solving exercise, that heres the problem ive got, ive got to solve it.

Call: yeah.
Response: because, you know, everything is reductionistic.

Call: the explanation that individuals with hoarding disorder have, those reasons that justify their behaviors, do you feel that those explanations are just post hoc reasons to justify a pathological need?
Response: yeah possibly, possibly.

Call: so, you would say that you feel that for a good portion of individuals there may be some kind of need thats being explained by psychological things or personality or whatever?
Response: i think so, i mean i think i think that its hard for people who are engaging in a behavior that they feel some degree of shame about not to make attributions about ones character, and its especially hard for family members of people with hoarding disorder not to make attributions about their character.

Call: ok, another, kind of tie in to that is do you think that or how much do you think that cultural forces associating value and self-worth with consumption and material possessions, how much do you think that that plays a role in the development of hoarding disorder?
Response: thats a good question.

Call: and what do you think the relationship is between hoarding disorder and compulsive or addictive shopping, or a disorder where it focuses more on acquisition or acquisitions of specific items?
Response: oh, i think theyre closely related.

Call: mhm. another question on the babs that we kind of wanted you to think through how your patients might respond is, how convinced are you that you need to keep these things or that something bad will come of discarding them?
Response: i think thats if its worded correctly, i think patients will say that they are convinced.

Call: well, something that were kind of trying to do these questions have been kind of challenging, more challenging for us to develop because the brown assessment of beliefs is much more geared towards obsessive compulsive disorder and INAUDIBLE.
Response: right, right.

Call: how do get an insight through these kinds of measures?
Response: yeah, yeah.

Call: so how have you, kind of, come to deal with this problem?
Response: well, if you want to talk about insight, i think for hoarding you want to go back to its original definition.

Call: INAUDIBLE
Response: yeah, yeah, we havent, but NAME and NAME and i spent a couple years trying to develop these, and we came up with a whole series of questions and just were never satisfied that they captured what we intended with insight.

Call: its interesting to hear you talk about it.
Response: yeah, its really, i think its a really hard problem to solve.

Call: or is that not the case?
Response: i dont know.

Call: we were just wondering if you could talk us through, from your experience, the typical process that occurs in order to get patients into your office for treatment or for study participation.
Response: well, i think for the most part, what happens is that people go through long periods of time where they are criticized by family members, pressured by family members, and then maybe the authorities get involved and so they one of the ways that people get in around here is when we run, we have a community forum on collecting and clutter and we make announcements about a very intensive workshop.

Call: and how long would you say that this behavior has been going on, typically, before they get to that point?
Response: usually decades.

Call: did it start when they were a child or young adult or develop later in life?
Response: well, the research weve done on it suggests it starts fairly early, about somewhere in between 10 and 20 years old, and although its not serious then, the behaviors begin then.

Call: is it your sense that its a progressive disorder in the sense that the behaviors worsen or is it a progressive disorder in the sense that they accumulate more and more stuff and so it appears to be worse over time because they have more later?
Response: yeah, thats a good question.

Call: and in terms of family and friends kind of playing a role in arriving at, you know, the diagnosis of hoarding disorder, do you have a sense of which family and friends are most often involved and how that goes?
Response: usually its adult children of the individual, and sometimes its a sibling, sometimes its a spouse, but the majority of the cases ive seen where the family gets involved its the adult children of an elderly person whos been doing it for many years and now may have had some kind of health setback and is going to have more trouble living in an environment that is heavily cluttered.

Call: landlords, police officers, you know, homeowners associations, those kinds of people.
Response: oh yeah, homeowners associations certainly are, health departments, elder service agencies, child and family services, animal control, they all have stories, and they all have cases.

Call: and, INAUDIBLE.
Response: in part.

Call: are there things about the dsm-5 criteria that you feel are sometimes challenging or particular elements that are difficult to apply where the different clinicians might apply differently?
Response: i think the dsm-5 criteria actually is quite well written, and the fact that they put insight and acquisition as specifiers rather than requirements is important.

Call: and thats because the criteria almost necessitates a certain amount of time span, you think, to build up that degree of clutter, or?
Response: i dont know if its time spent or absence of external factors controlling it, or if its just the natural progression of the disorder, but and obviously all the dsm criteria, all the dsm diagnoses requires a level of impairment or distress, but i think that the focus on clutter as one of the primary mechanisms of impairment is good at the severe end, but may not be good in the early stages.

Call: so with persistent difficulty discarding or parting regardless of their actual value, how are you determining value?
Response: thats hard.

Call: does home size play into this at all?
Response: home size does play into it.

Call: what do you mean by means?
Response: well money, insight, help, family members, etcetera.

Call: ok
Response: and thats ok if they go in and out and use it as a workroom, but if its got stuff in it and they never walk into it then thats an indication.

Call: could this be a similar, but more extreme difference?
Response: not sure i follow that question.

Call: so one of the ideas behind talking about clutter is that the space is filled and thats a problem, but are their people for whom they dont need to have as much free space in their home in order to live with a sense of ease or comfort?
Response: oh sure.

Call: is that kind of a cultural intended use or is that this individuals intended use?
Response: i think its kind of both, right?

Call: how do you go about determining how much distress is normal or abnormal?
Response: well i think that distress in discarding in general is abnormal, right, in that we may feel a little twinge of sorrow when we get rid of something that has sentimental value, but weve decided its time to go.

Call: and is it sometimes difficult to assess the level of distress that hoarders have?
Response: yeah, theres no real objective way to assess an internal feeling, right?

Call: what about if a patient is denying having a problem?
Response: so thats true for all disorders that have variable insight.

Call: are these explanations, in your opinion, post hoc reasons to justify pathological need?
Response: i dont know.

Call: what do you think has caused you to have these beliefs?
Response: behaviors, it would have to be for this, not beliefs.

Call: beliefs, behaviors, yeah.
Response: or difficulties.

Call: do these beliefs or behaviors have a psychiatric or psychological, neurological cause, or are they true?
Response: true?

Call: are they actually true?
Response: so true is not going to work for hoarding either because its not a true, right?

Call: how do you define insight?
Response: insight is the awareness of what your symptoms are and how they impact you and the world around you.

Call: how convinced are you of these ideas or beliefs about the value of things and the impact it has on your life?
Response: ok thats going to have to be reworded also.

Call: so you think that that low insight subgroup is
Response: not going to come in for treatment.

Call: would you say that its that you think prevalence wise or population wise it would probably be a 50/50 split?
Response: no, i think its a spectrum like this.

Call: in your experience are any of these more prevalent or more problematic in your work with these individuals?
Response: probably anosognosia and, to a lesser degree, not overvalued ideation but overvalued beliefs that these are going to be needed in the future, somebody is going to need these in the future.

Call: and defensiveness.
Response: defensiveness is a secondary phenomenon, i think, around, for people who have insight, a need to, well, defend their symptoms and behaviors, but i think its tied to insight.

Call: so, you cannot have defensiveness without insight?
Response: without a modicum of insight at least.

Call: do you feel like its normally self-motivated or by others?
Response: in my experience its been both, most of the people who come and stick in treatment its self-motivated.

Call: how long has the hoarding behavior been going on before you typically see patients?
Response: at the very least a decade and usually much longer.

Call: how aware, would you say, are typical patients that they have hoarding disorder when you first see them?
Response: well, because theyre in my clinic or in my research study, pretty aware.

Call: pretty aware.
Response: yeah.

Call: so, next im going to ask you, how do you explain hoarding disorder to a patient with low insight?
Response: i think that has changed over the years as my understanding of it has changed, but i explain that things are valuable to them, that even though theyre valuable there is some risk in keeping as many things as they have.

Call: ok.
Response: and thats changed over the years as ive kind of worked with folks more and more.

Call: is that something that you try to do?
Response: i think for those that are amenable to it a medical model can help.

Call: yeah.
Response: to me insight is, despite kind of a recognized, societally recognized understanding of something, your view of it is different and limited, and i dont think were there for hoarding disorder.

Call: so, what do you think causes a patient to fail to gain insight?
Response: i think its biology actually.

Call: how much do you feel like insight or the lack thereof impinges on an individuals quality of life?
Response: i think it can impinge on it quite directly.

Call: so, you feel like, we psychiatry, medicine is not in a place where we can directly treat insight, lack of insight.
Response: no, i think we can chip away at it, but i dont think we can directly treat it.

Call: yeah.
Response: we try with anorexia to kind of pound insight into folks, but i dont think its successful.

Call: can you speculate as to what goes into that shift to insight?
Response: for anorexia?

Call: for anorexia, what it would look like in INDISTINGUISHABLE
Response: i wish.

Call: and have you seen that variance in insight in individuals with hoarding disorder?
Response: mhm.

Call: what have you seen?
Response: i think theres two kinds of trajectories, one is over time with treatment, somebody who engages in treatment, their insight can shift for the better.

Call: yeah.
Response: kind of those breakthrough moments people talk about one way or the other.

Call: kind of the last set of questions i wanted to ask you were: what role do a patients family and friends play in arriving at a diagnosis of hoarding disorder?
Response: well if you can get collateral information its always very useful because patients can over and under report their symptoms, typically under report but also over report.

Call: what relatives do you find are most often involved in that process?
Response: its not necessarily relatives, its somebody living with the person, so living partners usually.

Call: ok. and do you whats the relationship between patients family, friends, loved ones living with them and their degree of insight?
Response: i dont know that there is a direct relationship.

Call: how often or how frequently are employees of the state, you know, social workers, police officers, homeowners associations, involved in cases of hoarding disorder and people coming in and diagnosing?
Response: so, the two different questions.

Call: well alright that is all the questions i have for you.
Response: theyre good questions.

Response: i feel like the age definitely is, and i just feel like in general women are more likely to seek out mental health services than men are.

Response: yeah.

Response: one part that gets and i notice its kind of the language with most of the diagnoses in the dsm is kind of the rule out.

Response: i go more based on what the level of accumulation in the house and how is it interfering... how is the clutter specifically interfering with the daily functioning?

Response: yes.
