Call: what makes the value judgement for a person with hoarding disorder inappropriate?
Response: i think its more i mean one of the challenges i feel here is when i ask somebody, and this is like a fire marshal, how do you know if its a hoarding disorder situation? hes like, well its like porn, you know it when you see it.

Call: so, it sounds like you make the determination less about each item and more about the pattern of items.
Response: yeah.

Call: and, does it matter which culture the patient is from or what their beliefs about items might be?
Response: i think its harder when its the emotional attachment to items or the emotional value because that really is so strongly based on an individuals experiences, or kind of how they define their identity.

Response: well, i think one of the big pieces is whats the purpose of that home?

Response: i think it does.

Response: i think that its a combination of the two.

Call: ok.

Call: so, again we were kind of wondering how you assess the degree of distress that somebody has with discarding an item, and whether this might be more difficult to assess in patients who dont have a lot of insight about the disorder.
Response: yeah, i think that if the individuals dont have the insight, or theyre also far enough removed from their stuff, they may think that they wouldnt have any difficulty letting go of the items, but then when theyre actually in the moment of dealing with the items, thats when the distress comes up.

Call: so, you might ask a patient in your office, would you get rid of this item? and they would say, yes, but then when actually confronted with the need to do it they would experience distress.
Response: right.

Call: but, they wouldnt they didnt even know they would experience it.
Response: or they would significantly underestimate the level of distress that they would expect to have.

Call: so, can you tell us how you define insight?
Response: i think it comes from, how did they explain the situation to me?

Call: what do you mean, externalizing?
Response: putting responsibility of the situation they didnt have the resources that they needed to be able to effectively organize the situation, the landlord was being unreasonable about how the space needed to be maintained, it really wasnt problematic.

Call: and, so do you have any knowledge about how patients successfully gain insight, or how you might help a patient try to gain insight?
Response: i think that a big part is in as nonjudgmental a way as possible kind of trying to point out kind of how are things connected.

Call: and, do you think that when patients kind of come to you with that insight already that that is something that theyve come to on their own or do you think that its often their families that assisted in the process?
Response: i think its often either the family, but i feel like theres been some kind of external event thats been sort of almost like a wakeup call.

Call: ok, so when they get some outside input.
Response: i think theres been some outside input.

Call: yeah, and things can also, i assume, become dangerous when individuals with hoarding disorder start to isolate, because then they dont have that
Response: that outside calibration, yeah.

Call: so, those constructs are defensiveness, anosognosia or the lack of ability to perceive your illness and the distress, the idea of overvalued ideation, unreasonable belief in the value of the items, and indifference.

Call: i think that falls into some kind of borderline category between indifferent and maybe overvalued ideation, not realizing what a big difference it would make.
Response: well and then also not prioritizing the actions that are tied into the decluttering.

Call: that makes sense.
Response: and, i think that the defensiveness, i think that depends on how youre interacting with them.

Call: so, theyre feeling like the need to justify themselves right off the bat INUADIBLE.
Response: right.

Response: ok.

Response: so what youre asking, what they tell me is the cause?

Response: yeah, they typically, they say those things.

Response: i would think that theyre justifications.

Response: every patient justifies their illness.

Response: and then the rationale.

Response: well, it depends on how old they are.

Call: so
Response: many years or decades.

Response: probably by their twenties.

Call: and, so how long has ithow has the illness progressed over time, how has it come to?
Response: over time, it seems to get worse.

Call: and then as they age, do you feel like the illness worsens or do you feel like, um, for instance social factors like the isolation of children leaving home or spouses dying or
Response: well those things have an influence because if the kids living at home, the mother might force them to clean up their room so when he leaves to live on his own, he can do what he wants because mom isnt there to force him to clean up.

Call: were kind of trying to get at whether that is because it is a progressive illness that worsens as people age or whether thats a result of, you know, possessions accumulating over time, perhaps changes in levels of their social support as they get older
Response: i think, i think all of the things contribute because a) they might not have a spouse to keep the hoarding in check, b) theyre older, so theyve accumulated stuff over a lifetime so they probably have more stuff or they have a large house and the kids are out of the home so theres more space to accumulate stuff.

Call: and when you look at the current state of research on hoarding disorder, what for you are the biggest unanswered questions about this disorder?
Response: could you repeat that?

Response: well, there are a number of things we dont know.

Call: and for you
Response: so theres this unaddressed need to develop effective treatments.

Response: because every single hoarder patient that ive had has been referred for cbt and usually experts in ocd who understand hoarding and theyve been trained in some of these models and the patient wont persist, the patient wont; its not that the treatment itself doesnt offer something, its that the patient wont do what the therapist tells them to do or they wont persist at it.

Call: umm, for you, where would you see hoarding on kind of like the spectrum between those differences?

Call: so do you
Response: its not a preponderant problem, but they have some tendency.

Response: no, no because most patients say you know, i really dont like this, its upsetting so, you know, we try to take the item away from them, we try to get them to throw it away.

Call: ok, well i really appreciate your time
Response: now, now there is a subgroup of people who hoard who might be said to have compulsive shopping, ive read quite a bit about that.

Response: the trauma explanation, no. the other explanation, ithat you mentioned saving because they grew up poor or something, to me thats environmental, so theres always an environmental component to that.

Call: so, for you when you think about hoarding disorder what are some of the most important differences between normal saving behavior such as perhaps collecting and hoarding disorder?
Response: well i think that probably the main one that distinguishes any pathology from its normative behavioral cousin is the degree of dysfunction that it entails.

Call: or is there a different way you would define impairment?
Response: that inability to do basic things in the home as well as the ability to live safety in the home.

Response: well theres sort of two different pieces to hoarding.

Call: okay.
Response: so i think there is probably two processes that kick in and thats why i think hoarding overlaps somewhat with the obsessive compulsive kind of disorders, but i also think it overlaps somewhat with the impulse control disorders.

Response: i think what really makes the difference for me is the degree of functional impairment.

Call: so, things like INAUDIBLE.

Call: is that the more common problem, is which disorder is it and not is this clinical or subclinical?

Call: so, the first one is: persistent difficulty discarding or parting with possessions regardless of their actual value, and so the kind of question we had about your application of this one is: how are you determining value, and how does that the value of the items that are saved play into the diagnosis of hoarding disorder?
Response: i think its very difficult to determine value because its so subjective.

Response: i think so.

Call: does that sound right?
Response: yeah.

Call: right.
Response: i think the reasons people give when you push them are not necessarily the actual reasons they are doing it.

Call: right and thats a question i was actually going to ask you later is: whether you feel the explanations are kind of post doc reasons to justify an underlying pathological need or if kind of the hoarding reasoning or thought processes is what came first or if the thought process is a product of them just justifying what they are doing?
Response: i love that question.

Call: so, for you its a behavior that they do and then they watch themselves doing it and then they come up with reasons why theyve done it.

Call: but it sounds like you kind of got on the biological side of that.

Response: yeah yeah.

Call: and how do things like the size of their home, or the amount of free space they have access to, or whether other people live with the, play into a diagnosis?

Call: right.
Response: and i dont know if we have a good way around that, i dont know if we have a good way of resolving that.

Call: do they then not have hoarding disorder because they dont have clutter?
Response: right.

Call: likewise, i kind of wonder how you judge the intended use of space, for instance if you have a guest room that you prefer to use for storage is that compromising intended use, or if you have a desk and the surface of your desk is covered with stuff as opposed to being open for space, you know some people prefer to use their tables to store things, and so i wonder how you judge the kind of intended use part of that criteria?
Response: yeah, the way that i do it this is just flying by the seed of my pants is just that its probably pretty normal to have a space or two that you dedicate to storage.

Call: so sometimes people prefer their spaces to be more cluttered, they prefer to have more items around them and sometimes hoarders
Response: yeah.

Call: about creating the space that they want to inhabit or is the space just kind of a byproduct of their need to save?
Response: i think its a byproduct, you know again i think that an awful lot of post talk rationalization that occurs.

Call: how is this distress kind of assessed by a clinician?
Response: its primarily based on the persons self-report, and we might ask if i challenged you to throw away a magazine, how would you feel about that and your trying to get a sense of the whether the person would say that would be awful, i would feel like my arms are being ripped off or something like that.

Call: so, kind of to lead into that, do you find that when your patients have what we would call low insight that they deny stress associated with discarding?

Call: how would you define insight?
Response: i would define insight according to three different variables.

Call: so, they may be aware that they have a problem but just not want to deal with it?
Response: they dont want to acknowledge it to you because they dont want to deal with it.

Call: are they mutually exclusive?
Response: they are not mutually exclusive.

Call: whereas people who are defensive
Response: right.

Call: whereas people who are defensive or who have overvalued ideation are at some level aware of the fact that they have a problem but either dont want to deal with the problem or continue to believe unreasonable things despite the fact that theyre
Response: precisely.

Call: is that what you mean by that?
Response: yeah.

Call: right.
Response: so, the person really and truly believes in their heart of hearts that this is a very valuable thing that theyre holding.

Response: i think it can vary i think probably the one i hear most often is either it has utility or that it has monetary value like, im going to sell it.

Call: do you feel like there is a role for indifference in thinking about insight or is that something
Response: yeah, i think of indifference as being sort of on the anosognosia spectrum.

Call: how do you help patients do that?
Response: its different.

Call: so, thats just kind of to help them to see, to perceive that they have a problem is really what you are getting at?
Response: right.

Call: for instance, if somebodys chief providence with overvalued ideation they might be aware there is a deficit but still have a delusion.
Response: well frankly, in a case like that im a little bit different.

Call: okay.
Response: in which my aim is more to help you critically evaluate what you are thinking and see if its realistic and maybe even do some hypothesis testing.

Call: and do you see these different kinds of insight as perhaps different points along a progress, do you feel like people start out with anosognosia and move towards defensiveness or overvalued ideation or do you think that thats not necessarily how it works?
Response: i dont think thats necessarily how it works.

Response: i think its a mixture of both.

Response: well most of them say they have been engaging in this behavior since adolescents or early adulthood.

Response: good questions.

Call: right, so there is maybe a progressive aspect but also a social aspect and as your social life changes over your life course the manifestation of your disorder might worsen.
Response: i think so, and theres an environmental aspect, which is just that it takes a long time for the stuff to reach a critical mass.

Call: so, the first question is if we were to ask one of your patients what do you think has caused you to have these behaviors and do they have a psychiatric or underlying biological cause, what is your sense that your patients believe is causing their hoarding disorder?
Response: i think that my patients would believe there is a psychiatric cause.

Call: and is your sense that they believe that its a biological illness, that there is a biological cause for their hoarding disorder or do they have psychological explanations for it?
Response: i think most would have more psychological than biological explanations.

Response: because i experienced trauma in my life or something like that.

Response: yeah.

Response: yeah.

Call: what do you think is the connection between memory and saving behavior in hoarding disorder?
Response: well its funny because you know most people with hoarding disorder have intact memory.

Call: so, they have anxiety about forgetting?
Response: i think they have anxiety about forgetting and i think, again it depends on whether you believe that those reasons are really the causes of the behavior or they are justification.

Call: and again, thats a very big question but.
Response: yeah.

Call: okay.
Response: literally we dont know anything about hoarding.

Call: okay those are some big questions to answer in the future.
Response: yes.

Response: sure, my pleasure.

Response: well thats why the INAUDIBLE piece is only one piece of it.

Call: but it sounds like with animal hoarding theres a lot more seeking out, so that maybe is a question i should ask you.

Call: is it more of an inability to discard?
Response: i think both.

Call: thats interesting.
Response: i mean its also a control issue too where if youre a caregiver and your whole sort of INAUDIBLE is centered around being perceived as a caregiver and providing care, then you cant provide care unless you have something that needs it.

Call: so, part of it is this identity of being a person who is a caregiver so identifying oneself as kind of like a good person because theyre taking care of so many dogs and cats, its a personal identity.
Response: yes.

Call: do you find that when you go into the home its cluttered and their car is full of stuff and also they have seventy-two cats?
Response: well again, it depends on how one defines the term hoarding because theres a difference between just the accumulation of stuff in my mind versus, because they just didnt throw it out like theres piles of trash in the kitchen and old food, unsanitary conditions, very crowded, but they never deliberately said oh, i want to collect INAUDIBLE.

Call: do people who hoard animals also hoard objects?
Response: yes, so you will see certainly when you come into some of these places and again theres a range of things, so sometimes yes, sometimes no. sometimes what you see is tons and tons of old pet food, bags of dog food, bags of cat food, empty cans of cat food, empty cans of dog food, you know litter bags, etc. so some of it is the INAUDIBLE of having animals and i dont know that theyre hoarding that, they just dont throw it away and thats just how their lives are organized.

Call: interesting.
Response: there was another case where we walked into the shelter and there was stall after stall after stall filled with chandeliers.

Call: interesting.
Response: so, yeah you see both.

Call: it sounds like with animal hoarders a lot of times they have collections.
Response: well, it can be all of the above is all im saying.

Call: and there does seem to be a parallel between seeking out animals to collect and seeking out chandeliers as opposed to with object hoarding where its just kind of like you said an accumulation of not throwing stuff out.
Response: even with object hoarding though i mean there are people that do the trash pickup every day.

Call: so, just because were seeing people with a lot of animals doesnt mean those people are necessarily similar in the reasons theyve acquired those animals or how they ended up becoming people who acquire a lot of animals.
Response: yeah, we dont know.

Response: bingo!

Response: well, probably not the ones who truly are hoarders.

Call: right, that shes listening to you describe her and shes not seeing it.

Response: well, the initial work we did and i think it has held up that they INAUDIBLE.

Call: wow.
Response: and shes been in litigation now with the NAME and the local community and shes got the means to be a very pretentious INAUDIBLE.

Call: that is so interesting.
Response: theres somebody who sort of, she doesnt challenge the INAUDIBLE type, but she challenges a few of the others.

Response: thats a very good point, NAME.

Call: do you see this as a behavior of a depressed person who cant really control their life and is perhaps trying to cope with depression?
Response: i wouldnt be qualified to make, im certainly not qualified by myself to make that judgement and we really dont have the data because nobody has done clinical diagnostics on these samples.

Call: like they are caught hearing voices?
Response: its a very vocal delusion is all i can say.

Call: its like a total blindspot about this one
Response: i mean there was NAME and NAME and their book NAME about a woman who was a psychiatrist in new york and she was a cat hoarder and she used to make her patients work with her cats as part of their therapy and she would encourage the patient to go home and collect their own population of cats.

Call: do you see patients clinically?
Response: yes.

Call: and you hold a phd in which field?
Response: no, md.

Call: oh, youre an md.
Response: yeah, im a psychiatrist.

Response: yeah, okay, so and then theres some literature and (inaudible, ) and colleagues on that and the differential.

Call: can you hoard in that way or is that a distinguishing feature?
Response: i mean i think sometimes there are.

Call: okay, so it sounds like its not about the type of item or even that there is a type so much as that access of different types that they might have collectibles and might have a collection in the midst of many, many other things.
Response: yeah and the motivation.

Call: do you feel like thats a distinguishing factor?
Response: yeah, because usually disorganization tends to be a prominent part of the problem in most patients with hoarding disorder and you dont necessarily see that with people who are just collecting something.

Call: so, are they ashamed of their items?
Response: i think theres a great deal of shame amongst people with hoarding who do have insight into their condition.

Call: that part of them realizes the behavior is problematic and thats why they kind of hide it away or is it something else?
Response: no, i think thats a big part of it.

Call: can you think of a specific case or cases that was challenging to diagnose because you felt like it was kind of on the border between pathological and normal behavior?
Response: i would say the cases that i found hard to diagnose were not so much because of the difference between normal behavior, they were more because of a question about what was the primary problem.

Call: how do you decide if a diagnosis of hoarding or a diagnosis of ocd, for example, is a primary diagnosis?
Response: so i think that probably the one thing thats most crucial is reason for saving.

Call: are there particular elements of these criteria that you regard as particularly difficult to apply or that you have ever thought different clinicians may apply differently or have to do with clinical judgement?
Response: yeah, i mean im biased because i wrote the first chapter of the criteria in my office a few years ago and then worked on the committee with the dsm-5 that worked on these criteria ten years ago or eight years ago.

Call: is that a part of this diagnostic criteria?
Response: no, no i dont think so.

Call: so im wondering how you figure that into your diagnosis.
Response: yeah, i think youre exactly right that the presence of clutter and the severity of clutter is influenced by a whole bunch of things that are completely external to the persons psychopathology and for that reason (inaudible, ) sort of hoarding special interest groups at the foundation and our little research conferences.

Call: or could it be intended for storage?
Response: right.

Call: so, for example, could one hoard digital media like digital photographs, digital, you know somebody who saved movies or books on hard drives obsessively.
Response: yes, ive had patients who actually filled up multiple hard drives you know with gigabytes and terabytes worth of stuff that they have downloaded.

Call: im wondering if you feel like that sense of being surrounded by items or being enclosed is part of whats going on in hoarding disorder.
Response: yeah, so thats another kind of area of subjectivity because it has to do with how people react to or what their own emotional sense is about openness versus closedness and clutter.

Call: does that make sense as a question?
Response: yes, and thats an important question that a bunch of people have tried to answer.

Call: like how does distress and insight...
Response: well actually what i find is the patients who have little insight are very distressed about discarding.

Call: but often what they mean is those people are not actually distressed by their behavior at all, theyre very distressed by discarding, but theyre not distressed by their own behavior.
Response: yup and that was a big debate and thats where there were (inaudible, ) and i disagreed because they were kind of writing the criteria and i think even one of their own rating scales, hoarding rating scales, that kind of implies that everybody with hoarding disorder has poor insight and doesnt want to discard.

Call: can you explain what you mean?
Response: yeah, there was this idea that if you had insight into it or somehow youre not bothered by the attempts to discard it, you dont have hoarding disorder.

Call: so how do you define insight?
Response: well, i think insight is multi-dimensional.

Call: if it was mostly externally driven, if it was mostly internally driven, how did people get there?
Response: so almost everybody in our clinic who has hoarding disorder is there because they know they have hoarding disorder.

Call: so, i dont know, i was very struck by this paper and this breakdown and i was just kind of wondering if you had read it, if you have thought about it.
Response: no, i think i remember seeing it but not going through it, so i didnt know about those four constructs or four factors that he was identifying.

Call: i know that were at an hour and i want to be sensitive to your time, are you okay continuing through these last couple questions?
Response: yes.

Call: so is it more of a cognitive driven or more of a, i dont know, i guess my question is breaking down so ill let you answer it.
Response: i think different patients do have different motivations or different combinations.

Call: if there is anything to that idea?
Response: i would say i dont think so.

Call: and kind of the second thing that people say sometimes about hoarding disorder is that its related to early experiences of scarcity or somebody whos experienced poverty and therefore reacts to it by having so much stuff and again is there anything to that idea in your experience.
Response: no, there isnt.

Call: and just kind of as a closing out question, for you what do you think is the biggest unanswered questions about this disorder?
Response: well, i think theres several.

Call: so now were just going to get into a kind of semi-structure qualitative interview, and to start that off id just like you to give me a really brief idea of your professional background related to hoarding disorder, how you are involved with either research or treating patients with hoarding disorder.
Response: yes, so i went to undergrad at NAME university where i majored in psychology and worked with several of the labs on campus doing research as an undergrad and became involved in a lab that studied anxiety and related disorders kind of more broadly, and so i ended up staying post my bachelors degree and getting a research assistant position there and a grant where i worked on anxiety treatment trials.

Call: i know you said that its not your primary focus.
Response: no, i do not.

Call: so in your mind, what are the most important differences between normal saving behaviors such as perhaps collecting or even extreme collecting and hoarding disorder?
Response: if i had to name one thing i would say its the impairment that it causes.

Call: i guess thats maybe a tricky question but what im trying to get at is people change their lives and things have an impact on their lives, but what for you is really the line that pushes something like that into something that is an impairment?
Response: thats a good question.

Call: can you think of a specific case or an example of a patient where it was challenging to diagnose them, because it was on the border between pathological and non-pathological behavior?
Response: yes, actually i can.

Call: so, for you the way that you made that distinction was that you took the cue from her in terms of her self-report of impairment or her self-report of distress.
Response: yes, yeah for some part some impairment was very much self-reported in the sense that i did not know personally about her finances and never interacted with her or her husband in the room in a therapy session.

Call: and so, in terms of making the clinical distinctioneven though it was kind of border line because she was self-reporting impairmentyou went with her take on the situation.
Response: yes, i mean i knew, given what she was presenting with, that that was the kind of reel on what she would fit diagnostically and i often times think about how would i treat this patient without necessarily making a clinical decision about a disorderparticularly when it can be a little bit, you know, maybe differentially, diagnostically could be a differential diagnostic question.

Call: or things that are related to clinical judgement?
Response: let me think about that for a second, thats a good question.

Call: does that sound right?
Response: yeah, thats sort of what im saying i mean ive definitely seen patients who have been depressed for a while, we actually just had a case recently where a guy came in, a veteran who denied hoardingim going to talk freely about this i hope that thats okayit was a very fascinating case that they had asked me to consult on where he was essentially, i mean it was very clear that he was depressed and depression is seen as common INAUDIBLE diagnosis along with hoarding its pretty well established in the last couple of years despite what people think about oc its actually depression thats more common, and for him he was very much clinically depressed and had been since deployment to the extent that he wasnt even getting out of bed to use the bathroom he was actually just peeing in water bottles and throwing them on the floor so there became this question that given the nature of his home and how much filth and trash and INAUDIBLE there was, whether or not that was hoarding or whether or not it was something else, and i mean, technically he wasnt discarding or parting with possessions and he denied having difficulties but yet he wasnt doing it so there was this weird kind of like, what is it? and thats an instance in which im feeling that the thing that separates hoarding from other disorders is the need to acquire and what that brings for you and to me he really wasnt similar to the oc and other related disorders like that impulsivity.

Call: how do you determine if an aesthetic valuation is an inappropriate aesthetic valuation?
Response: thats a very good question.

Call: how do you determine if a patient is appropriately valuing items?
Response: i guess sometimes its in the number of things that they evaluate as valuable.

Call: and not so much that they correctly value valuable items and throw away trash, you know what i mean?
Response: yeah that somethings have moreyeah thats a good way to put it.

Call: and how do you determine, for example, if a person lives in a trailer vs if the person has the ability to have a very big house with two or three rooms for storage, how does that play into your ability to make a diagnosis of hoarding disorder?
Response: yeah, thats a really good question, one that ive thought about a lot.

Call: or even going a step forward and using the surface of a desk to work on as opposed to using the surface of a desk for storage?
Response: yeah, i would say thats when i would consider it kind of like on the line and maybe more subclinical.

Call: how does that figure into it?
Response: home size?

Call: so if you can keep acquiring stuff and have it not impair your life, you dont have a disorder?
Response: that would be my thought, yeah.

Call: how do you assess distress in that context?
Response: that is hard, typically what i do when i was treating patients is we would do a behavioral experiment in the first session where i would actually ask them to bring in a couple of items, and the idea was that i was going to keep the items for a week and then they would be returned back to the patient just to kind of see and to get a gage like you know kind of like an actual behavioral design or experiment to check what their distress level was regarding parting with the item at the moment.

Call: so, they are able to self-identify themselves as having distress?
Response: yes, they are not as able to identify the impairment, i would say, thats where the insight comes in for me.

Call: and so, as weve talked about a lot of the literature surrounding hoarding disorder describes many hoarding patients as having low insight, and so the first question to start out with is how would you as a clinician define insight?
Response: i mean think that i often times define it in impairment as well.

Call: mmhm, so like acknowledgement of distress.
Response: yes.

Call: what level of insight do you think that most levels of patients that youve seen are?
Response: let me think of some of the patients that i remember treating.

Call: and in your experience with the patients that youve seen, do you have any knowledge of how they came to gain that insight on their own or what the process was of them realizing their disorder?
Response: for most of them it became impairment.

Call: ill go through the list again if that would be helpful.
Response: that would be.

Call: which is the most important for you with patients with hoarding disorder?
Response: thats a good question, ive definitely seen the first three in patients.

Call: and when you try to approach a patient who has low insight, what are some of the ways in which you help a patient to gain insight?
Response: i guess sometimes i try to do, in my approach, kind of like alongside of reflecting back like you dont see this as a problem so you cant think of ways in which this isnt the best for you.

Call: so rather than trying to force it on them, you get them to kind of say it.
Response: yeah, versus getting them to understand what are some of the benefits of changing the behavior?

Call: what do they think?
Response: thats actually a great question, ive actually talked with the people that ive worked with a lot.

Call: thats interesting, so she kind of saw hoarding as a self-protective, almost like a creation of a shell or a safe space?
Response: yes!

Call: do you think that the cognition justifies something thats going on in the brain and is justifying it, or do you think that the justifications are actually whats causing the behavior?
Response: gosh, thats a very good question.

Call: yeah, i agree that its a very difficult question to answer and its been very interesting.
Response: yeah, the questions youre asking are so fascinating.

Call: do you think that hoarding disorder and the things that kind of play into peoples acquisition and keeping things, do you think that there is an aspect to which cultural forces associating value and self-worth with consumption and material possessions and ownership, do you think that theres any association between those two kinds of ideas in hoarding?
Response: i think it would be hard for there not to be.

Call: do you think that that could have anything to do with the development of hoarding disorder, just because it seems like many hoarders talk about their possessions in terms of memory and forgetting?
Response: yeah, and whats the question?

Call: yeah, no, i guess i just wanted to talk about that or to see if you had any thoughts on that issue of if you had encountered that?
Response: i definitely have, i mean thinking about mardi gras like i said earlier, almost like every memory she had of mardi gras would be erased if she got rid of all the cups or maybe all the cups but one.

Call: and its interesting because it doesnt sound like the cups were necessarily a reminder that the event existed, but more something in between, you know what i mean, more of like a physical acknowledgement.
Response: representation of that, yes.

Call: like they think that the memory will be gone and they will forget the memory or is it--?
Response: yes, i think that they definitely think that and as a part of my masters thesis i actually did a memory INAUDIBLE and hoarders actually have really great memories, and thats been another interesting finding in the literature, that the memory deficits are all perceived, theyre not actually there.

Call: i dont think thats ever come up in an interview before but that is, i think that brings very true...its something that nobody else has picked up on and something that id like to talk to you about.
Response: yeah, its definitely fascinating.

Call: that they have trouble distinguishing between things that that should be remembered and things that are able to be forgotten?
Response: yes, yeah, i dont think ive ever thought about that but yes.

Call: i want to be respectful of your time throughout this interview so if we get close to running out of time at any point please just let me know and we will stop, okay?
Response: okay.

Call: so first i'd just like to have you briefly give me a background on your own work with hoarding disorder in terms of your educational background and also how you came to be interested in hoarding disorder.
Response: okay.

Call: and you're mostly concerned with seeing patients clinically?
Response: excuse me?

Call: you're mostly concerned with clinical care of patients with hoarding disorder?
Response: yeah, thats my, my work is clinical rather than research.

Call: so for you, what are the most important differences between what could be considered normal saving behavior, perhaps such as collecting, and hoarding disorder?
Response: well, i think the most important discriminating factor is that the hoarding has gotten to the point where its interfering with their living situation, often a precluding safe entry or exit from their home, or causing them to not be able to use certain parts of their home, or their car for that matter.

Call: so for you, the distinction between normal saving behavior or even, you know, borderline cases like somebody who's an extreme collector is whether their home is still safe for that and able to be used, is that correct?
Response: yeah, or they, you know, significant interference with their ability to use certain parts of their home, things like that.

Call: and could you just describe like how you, how you make a decision like that or does that never come up for you?
Response: i honestly think that the people where ive thought that they had hoarding disorder was really pretty clear.

Call: so very few borderline cases in your experience.
Response: yeah, i dont see much that, that really falls in the borderline range of this kind of thing, you know.

Call: so
Response: theres considerable overlap.

Call: so these, these disorders are common, and do you ever feel like it's difficult to determine if somebody is primarily suffering from hoarding disorder or if for example, they're severely depressed and are just unable to clean up their space, does that ever become an issue for you and your practice?
Response: the thing, realistically, i think theyre at the point where i think theyve got a real hoarding problem.

Call: so their primary problem might actually be depression.
Response: yeah.

Call: and as you mentioned, that's a fairly recent conceptual distinction and i wonder how you see that play out in your own practice or if you think its a valid distinction to be made.
Response: well, i think its a valid distinction and, again, in the past we used to consider hoarding just a variation of obsessive-compulsive disorder.

Call: so it seems like with that it is, in your mind, they are different, but they often can co-occur, although they can occur separately as well.
Response: right.

Call: just again, this is not, we're not trying to get statistically significant, we're just asking people about their experiences with their patients that they find that it's very common in the patient populations that they see to have it overlap with ocd symptoms or if in their experience, its to be expected.
Response: yeah, i, i think maybe 20-25% of people with hoarding are also people with ocd, i dontyou know, ithats a guess.

Call: i assume you do.
Response: [inaudible ) i cant quite hear.

Call: i was just wondering if you use, i assume that you use the dsm five criteria in your practice with the intent of diagnosing an individual with hoarding disorder.
Response: right.

Call: perhaps things that are related to
Response: i think that sort of generally true with the dsm, but i think theyre, theyre reasonably clear.

Call: i can read them to you if youd like.
Response: i actually turn to the right page, i...

Call: do you ever struggle with the idea of a hoarders possessions, having actual value?
Response: well, you know, some people obviously are saving things that, that do have some financial value that could be sold or, you know, could be collected, kind of thing.

Call: how does that fit into this criteria?
Response: yeah, yeah but, but theyre, theyre still collecting or hoarding in a way that doesnt, treats that actual value in a way that makes sense.

Call: yeah, that makes sense.
Response: it looks like, at least a reasonable amount of time theyre not treating it the way i would expect people to rationally treat things in terms of their value.

Call: so when you say rationally treat things in terms of their value, you mean, they might have a collection of objectively valuable items, but rather than, you know, selling them or displaying them, they just accumulate them.
Response: they pile them in a corner somewhere.

Call: how does that play into determining whether their possessions can just en-clutter their active living areas.
Response: well, i think even people that have got lots of resources and lots of property still can end up with what looks like hoarding, even if its, you know, not impacting them as much as it might somebody that has limited resources.

Call: do you feel like it's easier to develop or to identify hoarding disorder in somebody who has a smaller space?
Response: i dont know if it is i can think of some people that ive worked with who, you know, have plenty of resources and just have lots and lots of stuff in various places.

Call: do you find that those kinds of distinctions are at play in making a diagnosis of hoarding disorder or do you find that it's very clear cut and, intended use isnt easy?
Response: most of time it is pretty clear that, that there are significant parts of their home, for example, that are compromised in the, in the, you know like, they cant use the dining room table to eat at because its piled with stuff.

Call: did they just describe their living space to you, or do you have other ways of, of examining that question?
Response: well, my other really useful thing there is to, a, send a pictures and rating scale

Call: you use their rating scale.
Response: that, in years, you know, it, it was developed by name and company.

Call: and i wonder how you make the determination of how much distress is normal or abnormal when it comes to discarding.
Response: well, yeah if, if you can describe the, the sentimental attachment to an object that, again, fits with my conceptualization of how people usually think about objects.

Call: so it sounds like there's barely borderline cases for you that it's usually pretty clear cut that the attachment is extreme.
Response: pretty much, yeah.

Call: so the first thing i'd like to ask you is how you as a clinician understand the concept of insight.
Response: well, i think that i mean by the term insight is understanding that this particular way of dealing with things is really outside the range of what we expect in normal experience and is, in some ways, interfering with their living their lives.

Call: or have you seen patients that are still kind of low insight?
Response: its quite variable and it kind of depends on how they get here, but people who come seeking help for hoarding voluntarily usually have a reasonable amount of insight that this is a problem.

Call: whats your process for helping a patient with low insight?
Response: well i, you know, i want to talk to them about what exact things are happening.

Call: thats what you concentrate on.
Response: right.

Call: and, in your experience, the patients that come to you with high levels of insight already, how have they, or do you have any sense of how they have gained that insight on their own or before they've come to you?
Response: im sorry, i lost a little bit of what you said [inaudible )

Call: so when patients come to you and already are self-identifying as people who have a problem with hoarding disorder, do you have any sense of how they gained that insight or what the process was that led them to let them to come and seek treatment?
Response: thats a tough one.

Call: in your experience with people with hoarding disorder, do they, how do these different constructs breakdown in your patients?
Response: well, i think the anosognosia kind of thing is certainly a presentation that is not unusual, again, more often folks that are brought to treatment [inaudible ) seek it themselves.

Call: can you explain what you mean.
Response: excuse me?

Call: i dont, im not
Response: yeah, well, when we talk about people being defensive, i think its really conceptualized as, ordinarily at least, and, conceptualized as somehow youre approaching something that is unconscious sleep, triggering their distress or whatever, and thats a conceptualization model that i dont think makes much sense.

Call: okay.
Response: okay.

Call: so defensiveness is more of a behavior or reaction rather than a construct.
Response: yeah.

Call: so for you it seems that its more of a post hoc justification, but that theres still avoidance based reasons for why they do things.
Response: yeah.

Call: okay.
Response: anything can be avoidance.

Call: and i wonder if you have any sense for your patients how long their behavior has typically been going on before you see them?
Response: yeah, for most people it probably starts much earlier in life than we ever know about it.

Call: so it sounds like some little bit about this disorder is social and has to do with isolation, which is perhaps
Response: i think that increases it, yeah.

Call: i mean i guess theres also a cause and effect problem
Response: right.

Call: in terms of whether people grow more isolated because of their behavior or their, you know, more isolated status enhances their behavior.
Response: right, well i think it probably goes both directions.

Call: do you ever feel that there are cultural forces associated with value that associate value and self-worth with consumption and material possessions that may play a role in the development of hoarding disorder or that
Response: why, i think if its a factor, its not a dominant factor.

Call: so
Response: again, its related to these ideas that if i dont have something, then i wont feel bad.

Call: in your experience, how does that balance out in the patients that you see?
Response: well i think it varies across patients, but i think that both elements are likely to be present in practically ever hoarder.

Call: so for each patient theres a little bit of both, for some theres more of a positive acquiring, and for some there is more
Response: yeah, i think there is a variable mix, but i think most are present in practically everybody with hoarding.

Call: how do you feel that figures into
Response: i think its an important part of what maintains hoarding, but i think its because of misunderstanding of how memory works.

Call: so it seems to be the kind of like a, almost a cognitive mistaking the object with the memory.
Response: right.

Call: but if you were to answer one question, what question
Response: okay.

Call: so now were just going to get into a kind of semi-structure qualitative interview, and to start that off id just like you to give me a really brief idea of your professional background related to hoarding disorder, how you are involved with either research or treating patients with hoarding disorder.
Response: yes, so i went to undergrad at NAME university where i majored in psychology and worked with several of the labs on campus doing research as an undergrad and became involved in a lab that studied anxiety and related disorders kind of more broadly, and so i ended up staying post my bachelors degree and getting a research assistant position there and a grant where i worked on anxiety treatment trials.

Call: i know you said that its not your primary focus.
Response: no, i do not.

Call: so in your mind, what are the most important differences between normal saving behaviors such as perhaps collecting or even extreme collecting and hoarding disorder?
Response: if i had to name one thing i would say its the impairment that it causes.

Call: i guess thats maybe a tricky question but what im trying to get at is people change their lives and things have an impact on their lives, but what for you is really the line that pushes something like that into something that is an impairment?
Response: thats a good question.

Call: can you think of a specific case or an example of a patient where it was challenging to diagnose them, because it was on the border between pathological and non-pathological behavior?
Response: yes, actually i can.

Call: so, for you the way that you made that distinction was that you took the cue from her in terms of her self-report of impairment or her self-report of distress.
Response: yes, yeah for some part some impairment was very much self-reported in the sense that i did not know personally about her finances and never interacted with her or her husband in the room in a therapy session.

Call: and so, in terms of making the clinical distinctioneven though it was kind of border line because she was self-reporting impairmentyou went with her take on the situation.
Response: yes, i mean i knew, given what she was presenting with, that that was the kind of reel on what she would fit diagnostically and i often times think about how would i treat this patient without necessarily making a clinical decision about a disorderparticularly when it can be a little bit, you know, maybe differentially, diagnostically could be a differential diagnostic question.

Call: or things that are related to clinical judgement?
Response: let me think about that for a second, thats a good question.

Call: does that sound right?
Response: yeah, thats sort of what im saying i mean ive definitely seen patients who have been depressed for a while, we actually just had a case recently where a guy came in, a veteran who denied hoardingim going to talk freely about this i hope that thats okayit was a very fascinating case that they had asked me to consult on where he was essentially, i mean it was very clear that he was depressed and depression is seen as common INAUDIBLE diagnosis along with hoarding its pretty well established in the last couple of years despite what people think about oc its actually depression thats more common, and for him he was very much clinically depressed and had been since deployment to the extent that he wasnt even getting out of bed to use the bathroom he was actually just peeing in water bottles and throwing them on the floor so there became this question that given the nature of his home and how much filth and trash and INAUDIBLE there was, whether or not that was hoarding or whether or not it was something else, and i mean, technically he wasnt discarding or parting with possessions and he denied having difficulties but yet he wasnt doing it so there was this weird kind of like, what is it? and thats an instance in which im feeling that the thing that separates hoarding from other disorders is the need to acquire and what that brings for you and to me he really wasnt similar to the oc and other related disorders like that impulsivity.

Call: how do you determine if an aesthetic valuation is an inappropriate aesthetic valuation?
Response: thats a very good question.

Call: how do you determine if a patient is appropriately valuing items?
Response: i guess sometimes its in the number of things that they evaluate as valuable.

Call: and not so much that they correctly value valuable items and throw away trash, you know what i mean?
Response: yeah that somethings have moreyeah thats a good way to put it.

Call: and how do you determine, for example, if a person lives in a trailer vs if the person has the ability to have a very big house with two or three rooms for storage, how does that play into your ability to make a diagnosis of hoarding disorder?
Response: yeah, thats a really good question, one that ive thought about a lot.

Call: or even going a step forward and using the surface of a desk to work on as opposed to using the surface of a desk for storage?
Response: yeah, i would say thats when i would consider it kind of like on the line and maybe more subclinical.

Call: how does that figure into it?
Response: home size?

Call: so if you can keep acquiring stuff and have it not impair your life, you dont have a disorder?
Response: that would be my thought, yeah.

Call: how do you assess distress in that context?
Response: that is hard, typically what i do when i was treating patients is we would do a behavioral experiment in the first session where i would actually ask them to bring in a couple of items, and the idea was that i was going to keep the items for a week and then they would be returned back to the patient just to kind of see and to get a gage like you know kind of like an actual behavioral design or experiment to check what their distress level was regarding parting with the item at the moment.

Call: so, they are able to self-identify themselves as having distress?
Response: yes, they are not as able to identify the impairment, i would say, thats where the insight comes in for me.

Call: and so, as weve talked about a lot of the literature surrounding hoarding disorder describes many hoarding patients as having low insight, and so the first question to start out with is how would you as a clinician define insight?
Response: i mean think that i often times define it in impairment as well.

Call: mmhm, so like acknowledgement of distress.
Response: yes.

Call: what level of insight do you think that most levels of patients that youve seen are?
Response: let me think of some of the patients that i remember treating.

Call: and in your experience with the patients that youve seen, do you have any knowledge of how they came to gain that insight on their own or what the process was of them realizing their disorder?
Response: for most of them it became impairment.

Response: that would be.

Call: which is the most important for you with patients with hoarding disorder?
Response: thats a good question, ive definitely seen the first three in patients.

Response: i guess sometimes i try to do, in my approach, kind of like alongside of reflecting back like you dont see this as a problem so you cant think of ways in which this isnt the best for you.

Call: so rather than trying to force it on them, you get them to kind of say it.
Response: yeah, versus getting them to understand what are some of the benefits of changing the behavior?

Response: thats actually a great question, ive actually talked with the people that ive worked with a lot.

Call: thats interesting, so she kind of saw hoarding as a self-protective, almost like a creation of a shell or a safe space?
Response: yes!

Call: do you think that the cognition justifies something thats going on in the brain and is justifying it, or do you think that the justifications are actually whats causing the behavior?
Response: gosh, thats a very good question.

Call: yeah, i agree that its a very difficult question to answer and its been very interesting.
Response: yeah, the questions youre asking are so fascinating.

Call: do you think that hoarding disorder and the things that kind of play into peoples acquisition and keeping things, do you think that there is an aspect to which cultural forces associating value and self-worth with consumption and material possessions and ownership, do you think that theres any association between those two kinds of ideas in hoarding?
Response: i think it would be hard for there not to be.

Call: do you think that that could have anything to do with the development of hoarding disorder, just because it seems like many hoarders talk about their possessions in terms of memory and forgetting?
Response: yeah, and whats the question?

Call: yeah, no, i guess i just wanted to talk about that or to see if you had any thoughts on that issue of if you had encountered that?
Response: i definitely have, i mean thinking about mardi gras like i said earlier, almost like every memory she had of mardi gras would be erased if she got rid of all the cups or maybe all the cups but one.

Call: and its interesting because it doesnt sound like the cups were necessarily a reminder that the event existed, but more something in between, you know what i mean, more of like a physical acknowledgement.
Response: representation of that, yes.

Call: like they think that the memory will be gone and they will forget the memory or is it--?
Response: yes, i think that they definitely think that and as a part of my masters thesis i actually did a memory INAUDIBLE and hoarders actually have really great memories, and thats been another interesting finding in the literature, that the memory deficits are all perceived, theyre not actually there.

Call: i dont think thats ever come up in an interview before but that is, i think that brings very true...its something that nobody else has picked up on and something that id like to talk to you about.
Response: yeah, its definitely fascinating.

Call: that they have trouble distinguishing between things that that should be remembered and things that are able to be forgotten?
Response: yes, yeah, i dont think ive ever thought about that but yes.

Call: and just to begin, i would like if you wouldn't mind for you to just give me a brief introduction of your background related to hoarding disorder, your education and how you are involved with hoarding disorder.
Response: a ph.d. in behavioral analysis and my thesis was on hoarding in animal models, of the neural basis and evolution of hoarding in non-humans.

Call: what do you mean by individual differences?
Response: people who are not clinically diagnosed who vary on the degree to which they express tendencies for hoarding.

Call: or even on the extreme end of normal saving behavior, such as collecting, and hoarding disorder?
Response: i think its normal, and everyone, to some degree, saves things they think might be useful or memorabilia.

Call: so the environment itself is what distinguishes it.
Response: i would say for the most part, but id say someone with a clinical disorder is not receptive or malleable like, to intervention.

Call: okay.
Response: so like, if its a person who has a hoarding tendency but they dont have a disorder, if you went to their house and you tried to help them go through things, they can probably do it.

Call: that makes sense.
Response: theyre more resistant than a typical person.

Call: did you ever?
Response: whats the question exactly?

Call: just to have you talk through a specific case that was particularly difficult to decide whether or not it constituted hoarding disorder and how you ended up making the decision, of what, of what it was or what it wasn't.
Response: well, for example, we have cases where people have extremely full areas of the house, like a garage or basement or an attic.

Call: and so for you
Response: yeah.

Call: does that sound right?
Response: right.

Call: do you find that those distinctions are difficult to make?
Response: not really.

Call: so their house is completely filled with like sports memorabilia or something like that, but not indiscriminate items?
Response: yeah.

Call: how do you decide if, how do you use that value criteria in the dsm-5 criteria?
Response: well, theres a lot of objects in hoarding where, like you paid money for it, but then as a used item, its almost worthless.

Call: so literal
Response: so, if they wanted to sell it, would they get really money for it that would be the [inaudible ) of lunch more than like, pocket change.

Call: but the items that they're hoarding are actually objectively valuable.
Response: i think that is extremely rare

Call: sure.
Response: to think this, this extremely rare, its certainly not like, very typical case.

Call: okay, that makes sense.
Response: yeah.

Call: even if it substantially compromises the intended use of the space?
Response: yeah, i would say [inaudible ), like theres some, like, magical case where it has no bearing on their life, and now, i just think its like so unlikely, ill just sign off.

Call: okay. so, kind of taking a step back from the dsm-5 criteria, when you think about the criteria overall, are there any elements of the criteria that you find particularly difficult to apply to patients or that you sometimes wonder that different clinicians might apply differently or that are more or less reliant on clinical judgment?
Response: i think its weird for them to say that it has to include distress, to a point of distress, because the patients have so little insight and theyre so, like, self-justifying in their behavior.

Call: i understand.
Response: which is a reason i think it's hard to treat because they don't show up at the clinic because they don't want help.

Call: right, so the problem with
Response: thats what i think is weird.

Call: yeah, the problem with insight prevents them from being distressed unless, unless somebody is trying to take their stuff away essentially.
Response: right.

Call: is that a part of this distress resulting from accumulation in a space and not being able to use that space?
Response: i would say no because i think people buy and still to the extent of the space and capacity for doing so.

Call: right.
Response: like, that you should be getting rid of but refuse to, its filled with stuff like you actually need but you have trouble finding somewhere to put it.

Call: is it pretty clear?
Response: i don't think it matters what culture was assigned the use for that room, i just think it matters like, what you need to be doing on a daily basis is compromised.

Call: so
Response: i do think thats a factor, yes.

Call: okay.
Response: i think because of the fear element, having the item surrounding a person, its like literally a sense of security and they feel uncomfortable in empty areas or cleared out areas.

Call: so, when people with hoarding disorder prefer cluttered spaces aesthetically almost, they feel more comfortable in them.
Response: and not even cluttered, but like literally fortress-like.

Call: how would you define insight?
Response: being aware that you have a problem that is not typical and that would be better off un-needing it.

Call: sure.
Response: it would be better for the individual, in themselves, if it were addressed.

Call: when you see patients in your research, how much insight do they tend to have when you first see them?
Response: i actually think, like the people i see, are not in the clinic, theyre coming for research, and they responded to an ad for pack rats or hoarders.

Call: so it sounds like they may have pretty low insight, for the most part.
Response: yeah.

Call: so with your patients that you see in research, what, which if any of these concepts, or these constructs that go into insight is most important?
Response: id say that i would agree with the existence of all of them.

Call: overvalued ideation, which is a persistent and unreasonable belief in the potential value of items that can range from mild to delusional, or else indifference or you just don't, don't really care, if there is a problem.
Response: i think that over-valuing is the winner, and defensiveness is a problem.

Call: so it sounds like for your patients with low insight, it is almost like a delusion when they look at their things, they see something different than what other people would see.
Response: right.

Call: so they look at the same pile of items and they, they see, you know, that it would be, they would estimate that it will be worth a thousand dollars, whereas, you know, you would estimate that it'd be worth nothing or smaller amount of money.
Response: right.

Call: so, to rephrase that question, which comes first, you know, the explanation for saving or the saving, do people just save and then justify their behavior or are these reasons that they give really the reasons that they do it?
Response: i think thats a very difficult question to answer.

Call: when did it start generally in the course of their life?
Response: sure.

Call: and is your sense of why that i because the behavior itself worsens like a progressive disorder, or is it more related to social forces, ;ike having the ability to have your own house or becoming socially isolated?
Response: i would say it has to be both.

Call: so both progressive and related to social process.
Response: yeah.

Call: do people who are hoarders tend to be more isolated or, or do you think that it's more that their hoarding makes them isolated.
Response: no, i think they start, theyre more isolated.

Call: okay.
Response: i think just like fear and anxiety, and then depression that feeds into hoarding disorder makes people, yeah, prefer to be alone and to protect themselves from others.

Call: do you feel like that's a part of it?
Response: sure.

Call: what do you think, what do you think is the relationship between the behavior and the sense of memory or what people think about memory?
Response: i dont think its as strong as other factors.

Call: so it might be a part of why people might say that they save things, but you don't think that, for example, people with hoarding disorders are more anxious about their memories or feel like they have poor memories or anything like that?
Response: there was a research study that said they do think they have poor memories.

Call: and, but in your experience, its not every patient.
Response: i dont think its like, a requisite necessary or sufficient.

Call: or if you could answer one question about hoarding disorder, what would it be?
Response: i think theres probably like an early developmental sequence, like an epigenetic sequence that combines like a genetic predisposition and early life experience to create this hoarding disorder.

Call: so the ways that all these different factors come together.
Response: correct.

Call: the way that i like to start out is have you talk through from your perspective as a clinician, what are the biggest and most important differences that in your mind distinguish people with hoarding problems form normal saving behavior, maybe perhaps extreme collecting, and this disorder?
Response: yeah, so it's interesting that part of it really kind of depends upon the space that the person is living in and the number of possessions.

Call: it's kind of a question.
Response: no, so i wouldn't make the hoarding diagnosis unless there's impairment, and impairment would come from the lack of functionality of the space or the distress level.

Call: so, if hoarders have low insight and they're not necessarily distressed by their own behavior, is somebody who's not experiencing what they would call distress, who prefers to keep their possessions rather than say, you know, have a social life, are they going to get the diagnosis of hoarding disorder?
Response: yeah, i mean, it doesn't necessarily, in my conceptualization of it the way i always try to make diagnosis is distress doesn't narrowly have to be experienced by the individual in the primary sense.

Call: they might not be distressed about the presence of the items, but hypothetically discarding causes them distress?
Response: yeah, no, i mean many people are not distressed at all by the presence of the items, it would be just if they parted with the items or they maybe stressed by the arguments or the embarrassment that comes as a secondary result of the presence of the items.

Call: so, if somebody had their house completely full of items but they were all very orderly and they knew exactly where they were, would that still meet criteria?
Response: um, yeah so i think it matters completely about how it's organized and you can't go based on the total number of items, but it's whether the space is still functional and whether there's any hazard.

Call: is that where you draw the line?
Response: no, i think it depends on the way the person wants to use the space.

Call: so, it really depends on how they want to use their space and if they want to use it for so-called intended use, the intent is the patient's intent in that criteria.
Response: well, and the family intent.

Call: and have you ever encountered something that you might call a boarder line or a subclinical case of hoarding problems or hoarding disorder?
Response: sure, yeah, i think it's the tachometric studies that adjust it on a range of severity and you know, some people have a level of clutter that approaches compromising or somewhat compromises the living space but doesn't all the way make it unusable, so sure.

Call: so, you have to make diagnostic decisions in those cases based on how compromised the living space is.
Response: yeah, it's probably a range of things.

Call: is that ever a difficult distinction for you to make or do you feel like that's usually pretty straight forward?
Response: no, i think it is difficult, it can be quite difficult, particularly with hoarding behavior as a result of ocd versus a hoarding behavior that's a hoarding disorder.

Call: does that sound right?
Response: yeah, that sounds right.

Call: either things to do with the language or the use of clinical judgment?
Response: um, i mean i think it's relatively straight forward.

Call: and when you sit down with patients, do you have them bring picture of their space or do they describe their space?
Response: yeah, i do, i try to do home visits when possible so i can see it, but if not, then yes.

Call: would that fit criteria and how would you think about that in terms of the criteria?
Response: yeah, that's interesting.

Call: that they might say something like, "oh no, i could throw this away any time and it wouldn't bother me," despite the fact that they don't do that and if that ever presents a problem for you?
Response: yeah, definitely people will say stuff like that, "i could get INAUDIBLE if i wanted to, i just don't want to."

Call: so, they might think generally it would be better for me if i had fewer things and i would like to discard, but in the particular instance, that's when they experience the distress.
Response: exactly, yeah.

Call: how would you define insight?
Response: recognizing that the saving behaviors are excessive, or that they're problematic.

Call: so excessive in the sense of above the norm or different from normal, and also causing problems in your life.
Response: yeah, i think most people could recognize that they own more possessions than other people, so they would be insightful in that sense; but, where they might not be insightful is recognizing that this is a problematic number of possessions to have given the space you're living in.

Call: i would read them again.
Response: what was the first one?

Call: and being indifferent to the state of their home and the state of their space.
Response: yeah, i think probably in terms of which is more important, i think the first and the last.

Call: that's a question i ask because some clinicians will describe that like patients will look at their space and be clutter blind, that they'll be unable to see the space for what it really is, and that almost sounds like, maybe not a delusion maybe that's too strong, but that's like an inability to perceive the reality of their situation and i wonder if you see that at all with your patients, or if you see it as maybe less common that patients really can't see the clutter?
Response: i think the it can happen, but being in treatment is like a selection bias, when someone is in treatment, and in particular if you're doing home visits with them because you're there is a novel, a new set of eyes, it makes them see it too.

Call: have you ever encountered in your practice an individual with animal hoarding?
Response: i have not, no.

Call: so on your first visit with a patient, at what level of insight do they tend to be?
Response: that's a good point, if they're having me come over, then they have sufficient insight to recognize that it's at least something that they want to involve a professional at.

Call: and what are some of the things that you talk about with patients or that you do with patients to help them to gain insight?
Response: um, i know there's like visualization exercises that we can do to like imagine things being different or ask them if the clutter wasn't an issue for them, what would their life look like to try to get at what the clutter is blocking them from, or what would be different if the clutter weren't there, to try to have something to move towards.

Call: and do you have any sense for the patients you see clinically of that process of how they got to your office, or of what started them down the road of seeking treatment if it was, if it's primarily social family members or if there's kind of like a commonality if they decide to come see you?
Response: yeah, no , it's a range of different things, like some people have come to see me because of themselves, because this has been a problem or something that i've wanted to work on for a long time and for whatever reason now is the time.

Call: do you have any sense for that process or any kind of.. i know that that's maybe not a testable question, but i guess i'm asking you to speculate about how that works.
Response: um, that's a good question.

Call: i don't know if that seems like a fair synopsis of what you just said.
Response: yeah, that makes sense.

Call: you know like, how long it's been going on before people come to see you, if people talk about it being something in their life their whole life or something that has only developed recently?
Response: i think most people i see have a tendency to hang onto things, it has been there for like a long long time.

Call: so, that's kind of my next question, is your sense of that progression that it is, for example, related to trauma or neurocognitive decline over the life course, or it it more social in the sense that people who are older tend to be isolated and also to have had more time to accumulate items, and perhaps inherit them from parents dying and things like that?
Response: yeah, i think it's one of the second ones, i don't think it's necessarily like a neuro, i mean i'm not a brain scientist, but i don't think it's necessarily like a neurological degenerative disease.

Call: okay, so now we're gonna move onto the open-ended part of this interview. so just to begin, if you wouldn't mind setting the stage for me by briefly telling me your background related to hoarding disorder, your educational background, and whether you are a clinician who sees patients of a researcher or both.
Response: so i'm an md psychiatrist, i'm a clinician investigator. i've been working in the area of ocd since doing a fellowship in 1992 and in practice since 1992. i'm an academic who does research primarily on neurobiology, mainly genetics, of ocd and spectrum disorders, as well as developmental treatments and improving outcomes with treatment. my experience is primarily in ocd for the first 10-15 years of my career, and then gradually more inclusively to focus as well on ocd-related disorders. so, for the last 15 years or so, clinically working more with hoarding disorder, trichotillomania, and skin-picking disorder. i developed, i ran, i started running group protocols for cbt for hoarding and so i see individual cases for psychopharmacology and to some extent, for some individuals cbt typically limited by time constraints. i started running cbt groups for hoarding disorder about 10 years ago now, probably run about 8-10 cbt groups, began working on... i did training with NAME about 8 years ago. let me think... limited research, trying to develop community initiatives to work with our community agency so that they would be more informed in the cluttering aspects that they had going by a cbt model, i've done extensive teaching in the community, i've co-organized or organized about 7 to 8 hoarding conferences, and about 8 ocd conferences in which we usually have a hoarding sub focus with seminars or workshops on hoarding. i've been consulted by a number of local, well ontario actually, widely community groups, coalitions that they form, um, yeah, currently running more of a hurried treasure professionally lead, morphed model of group therapy for our clients here for our patients here.

Call: okay, thank you for that. um, so it sounds like you have a very broad experience, both with individual patients, with research, and with working with communities. so, for the first part of our interview, we're trying to focus on how you conceive of hoarding as a disorder, how you diagnose it, how you know it when you see it. and then we're going to move to the discussion of insight, and the purpose of this process is to understand how clinicians are looking at hoarding disorder, and then to talk to patients about how they identify the disorder in themselves and the purpose of that is to help understand the patient process of gaining insight. so, for you as a clinician, what are some of the most important differences between normal saving behavior, such as perhaps collecting, and hoarding disorder?
Response: so the excessive accumulation of material to the point that it impairs their ability to function. it's not organized as in a collection, it's not useful as in a collection, it takes over and impairs their ability to function. people with hoarding disorder typically are distressed by it, unlike collectors, and describe difficulty discarding, which collectors will not except perhaps in relation to the enlargement of their collection and material that may be a little peripheral to it. excessive acquiring of items.

Call: so it sound like the biggest difference in your mind that there are kind of maybe, it sound like from what you just said maybe two main differences. one is that the items themselves are so excessive and exist in a disordered state that they can really impair the person's ability to function; while in a collection, you wouldn't expect such excessive acquisition and they would be more organized and it wouldn't impair function. does that sound right?
Response: yeah, and displayed suitably, maintained, controlled, yeah. without the difficulty discarding, generally speaking, that we see in hoarders. so in hoarders, i look for a pervasive difficulty discarding, saving of everything, it's not thematically connected, it's not necessarily a collection at all, it has nothing to do with collecting, often the presence of insight, the recognition that it's excessive themselves but not always.

Call: could you have a person with hoarding disorder who hoards particular items? so, somebody who fills their home completely with cuckoo clocks or clown memorabilia. so, i guess what i'm getting at is is the non-discriminant aspect a key, or is it possible to have a patient with hoarding disorder who is discriminating to come extent, along the lines of the ways that a collector might?
Response: i guess i've seen some who have that, i mean usually all hoarders gravitate to certain kinds of material. so, if it's newspaper i don't think most people would think of it as collecting, but i've also seen hoarders who's collection, one guy for example, who collected model cars. but, again, his accumulation of cars was excessive, he had multiples of cars, they had overtaken his home to the point that he could not live in it appropriately, could not have people over, was worried about it being a fire hazard and getting inspected, he identified himself as unable to discard things or part with things. and so, even though there was a thematic connection, and some qualities in common with a collector, it went way beyond.

Call: can you think of ever encountering a case or cases that was really on the borderline and was challenging to diagnose for that reason, where you were really unsure if it was hoarding disorder or not?
Response: hoarding vs. collecting? no.
