Response: i certainly think the defensiveness is the one that resonates the most. that's something we just see day in and day out, even from folks that are willing to work with us and i think a lot of it seems to come from the fear that we're not gonna understand their stuff or value their stuff and that we're gonna judge them. they know that the system overall can be very punitive, and so what we find is once we make it clear that we're not gonna take their stuff because that's not our role, or tell them what to do, that they have control of their stuff no matter what, the defensiveness seems to break down. a lot of it really seems to be very fear-based.

Call: um, when you encounter people who have this disorder and have very low insight, would you say that they truly don't know that there's anything different about them or their lives than other people? that they're truly bling to the fact that they have something about them that's different? or is it more that they don't acknowledge that that difference is a problem?
Response: it feels like they know that not everybody else sees their stuff in their situation the way that they do, and aren't able to see the reasons that that might be a problem. i don't think it's willful disobedience or willful avoidance in most cases, but in some cases sometimes it might be. you know, i think a lot of it is all centered around perception and ability to kind of do the analysis that is required to have accurate perception.

Call: so would you say that when one of those individuals looks at their space, that they can't see how cluttered it is? that they see a normal space, even when it's clearly not normal?
Response: well normal for them at least. you know, i think they can't see the health and safety issues and the volume in the same way that the rest of us would see.

Call: and do you feel like that's just because they're so used to it or do you feel like that's almost in the level of like a delusion?
Response: i think it's hard for me to know sometimes. there are certainly some people where they just do not see it, and then there are some people where they might say, "oh it's a little bit messy but it's not that bad." as we're looking at something that's fairly severe. and so, you know, i generally don't think that it's avoidance as much as it is sometimes it feels like the brain's not giving them accurate data to work with.

Call: mhhm, and do you feel--i'm assuming that you've encountered also individuals that have problems with animal hoarding, because of your role. is that correct?
Response: right.

Call: do you feel like that's different for those individuals?
Response: you know, we don't have that many cases that come across every year so it's sort of hard to tell.

Call: okay.
Response: there's certainly a different level of attachment to the animals and an inability, when there's poor animal care, to be able to see it that feels a little bit different from object hoarding, but certainly that's not...again, we don't see that many so it's sort of hard for me to say.

Call: when you think about the individuals that you've encountered with this disorder, do you have any sense for how long the behavior's been going on before you see them?
Response: certainly for most of our folks, decades. you know, dating back to late teens, early twenties.

Call: and i guess just as you encounter these individuals, do you think that it's like a progressive illness that gets worse with age, or do you see it more as a set of circumstances? so like, as a person ages they naturally become more socially isolates, their children might leave home, they might inherit things from their parents, they might have a fixed income, and that those are the things that make it get worse as they get older?
Response: you know, we're not seeing people who are going out and actively acquiring all the time later in life, especially since they're frail, it feels like it's more of a, when you think about how much stuff builds up over a course of decades if you're not able to get rid of it, either through active acquiring or through things like junk mail that just come into our lives, it feels like it's more of a slow slide off of a slippery slope than anything else. it just kind of builds up and builds up and builds up.

Call: so, maybe it's more that the stuff has built up rather than the behavior has gotten recently worse?
Response: correct.

Call: okay, perfect. well thank you for doing that with me, we're going to move into the more unstructured fun part of the interview. just to begin with just as we get into that, would you mind telling me a couple of sentences about your background related to hoarding disorder and how you encountered individuals with this disorder?
Response: we started a program here at INSTITUTION in 2006, because we were seeing a lot of people who were losing their section 8 housing subsidies because of failed inspections caused by hoarding behavior. so we partnered with INSTITUTION and developed an evidence-based case management program for hoarding intervention to reduce the risk of housing loss due to hoarding behavior.

Call: and what is your professional and educational background?
Response: my professional, i actually don't have an undergraduate degree, and my professional background initially was doing hiv/aids work in the mid 90's in north carolina, and then moving to boston and doing housing work as a community organizer around various housing issues. and then i started doing some work in our code department here at INSTITUTION and that's how we've sort of taken hoarding and i've decided there's gotta be a better way to address the issue and that's when we got some training through INSTITUTION and INSTITUTION.

Call: and are you involved in diagnosing people with hoarding disorder, treating them, or research or all of the above or none of the above?
Response: so we don't do diagnosis. we're less worried about the mental health diagnosis, our goal is to provide case management intervention so that people aren't losing their homes. and so, if you think about treatment more broadly and less kind of clinically, you know i guess you could make an argument that that what we're doing, that our focus is not on the mental health side, it's on the social service intervention side. in addition to that, we've partnered with INSTITUTION to do some research because we have a very large data base of information that we've collected over the years, to better understand the problem of hoarding as we see it in the community so that we can have a better response in terms of housing stability and eviction prevention.

Call: and how long have you worked with these individuals?
Response: since 2006.

Call: so, now we're gonna talk a little bit about the diagnosis of hoarding and we have some questions, which we kind of use with clinicians but i'm really curious to your encounters with them and your ideas about them, so if you don't feel like these pertain particularly to you that's okay. the first one is kind of broad, so in your mind, what do you think are the most important differences between normal saving behavior, such as perhaps somebody who is a collector of items, and somebody with hoarding disorder?
Response: good question, i think there are a couple of different things. i think that the volume of possessions certainly is one. you know, with collectors, generally speaking they're able to display things, you could still use the homes and the rooms, the spaces for their intended purpose and i think when we think about hoarding, that impairment of the ability to use the space and the real risk of it in terms of health, safety and well-being is a bigger factor, so i think that that's the big kind of difference there that we see.

Call: so it's more about the home use itself and whether the person's space usage is impaired?
Response: yeah that's a big part of it, and you know i think the emotional attachment is different. i think for people with hoarding based on our experience, there's a lot of worry about what happens to the items if they're not being used, there's a lot of worry about the person collecting the items, their individual emotional and physical well-being if they didn't have the items, and so i think that that's also distinct form what you would see from a collector. it's a much more personalized attachment.

Call: so it sounds like there's two kind of main distinguishing factors for you. one is that unlike collecting, in individual with hoarding disorder's space will be kind of difficult or dangerous to use. and then the second one is that they'll have a much more kind of intense, maybe fear-based emotional response to their item? does that sound right?
Response: yeah, along with, you know not just fear-based, but an inability to separate out their identity, potential identity, all of those kind of emotions from the physical objects themselves.

Call: and have you ever encountered a person where you were unsure if they truly had hoarding disorder? maybe a borderline case or a case that wasn't a usual, where you felt like you just weren't sure or you struggled whether this was what was really going on for the person?
Response: um, not really. i mean, most of our cases are pretty straight-forward in terms of, you know, when people are talking about their stuff or what they worry about if they did get rid of their stuff, that in combination with the sheer volume of possessions that we see. i can't think of a case where we were unclear. certainly where we do run into issues is, and this is very different from looking at things clinically obviously, but we have folks who have other mental health issues such as schizophrenia or something like that. so sometimes for us, we're addressing the hoarding behaviors because that's what we're there for, but sometimes it's not clear, is the other mental health issue the primary factor, or is it the hoarding? and i think that's where it gets tricky and it's very different than how this would be clinically diagnosed.

Call: and how do you deal with those situations?
Response: you know, in a lot of the situations we'll do more behavioral work, you know, we've got a partnership with our department of mental health, we work with a lot of their more challenging individuals who will do a lot of things like using blue painter's tape to create an egress path and working with the individuals to get them used to keeping that egress path clear and then reducing the height of piles and getting them used to doing that by using other visual cues. and so, we're much less focused in those situations on the cognitive side and are really primarily focused on using harm-reduction and the behavioral side of things.

Call: and it sounds like maybe unlike a typical clinician, for you what's really important is making the person safe to live in the home and what's causing the behavior is almost less important than that. i mean if they have, for instance, obsessive compulsive disorder other than hoarding, if their house is full of stuff for you the primary thing to deal with is the house. does that sound right?
Response: correct, you know and doing the work to teach them the skills so that they can maintain it moving forward. we have a very low recidivism rate because our approach is regardless of what might be going on, if there is a different diagnosis that would be clinically given, that's less what we're worried about. we're really worried about teaching them the skills so that they can not only reduce the volume of their housing, but maintain it moving forward.

Call: one of the things i asked you about in the listing portion of the interview was about how you could tell if somebody had hoarding disorder. i'm wondering if in your mind as somebody who works with these individuals a lot, there's kind of like a soft set of criteria or a typical description of a person with hoarding disorder? do you feel like if you were to describe a person with hoarding disorder without actually talking about their stuff, that like a cohesive description of that person would emerge? does that make sense as a question?
Response: it does, and you know it would be so hard to do because all of our folks are really kind of different in terms of our, if you look at our data folks tend to be single, tend to be in their 50s or 60s, our folks have an average income of 13,000. that's because our program is primarily geared to work with lower income folks who are kind of most vulnerable around housing situations. but overall it's interesting because they're actually much better educated than our group in boston, which is a fairly well-educated population. so, you know, i think it's tough to make some generalities without kind of looking at their particular relationships with the stuff.

Call: i guess i'm, i don't know, sometimes when i ask for that list, even with clinicians i get this kind of very kind of personality-based description. you know, like somebody who's really scattered, who's very vivacious and talks a lot, and i'm wondering if that resonated with you as to the people that you see, that they kind of have this typical manner of being?
Response: it's interesting because you say that and in some of the folks that description is very very accurate, and then there's a lot of folks where that wouldn't be accurate at all, that they're very kind of hyper-organized and very quiet or very exacting. and so, i would feel really uncomfortable actually making a generality.

Call: mhhm, that's exactly, yeah.
Response: because we see such a wide range in terms of personalities. i think the thing that is much more consistent is the themes around why people hold onto their stuff.

Call: mhhm, interesting. so, now i have a couple of questions that deal with the specific diagnostic criteria, and i know that that's not really how you look at this problem, but i still want to kind of think through these issues with you. so, the first one is about value and when we talked about what distinguishes a person who has hoarding disorder from somebody who's a collector, you mentioned that the person with hoarding disorder their space will be much more kind of impacted and unusable, and i'm wondering if in your mind the value of the items saved is relevant to whether or not somebody has hoarding disorder? so, could you be a person with hoarding disorder who exclusively saves one kind of item in the same way a collector might? you know, like you can imagine somebody's house is totally filled with like cuckoo clocks to the point that they can't use it, but that's all they save.
Response: yup, you know and i think one of the interesting things is that they've taken the definition has changed around hoarding over the years. you know, the language around the definition used to say, "items that have little or no value," you know, but what we know is that people hoard all kinds of really nice stuff and really not nice stuff and i think a lot of it goes back to beauty is in the eye of the beholder. we certainly see people who hoard all of one thing, and sometimes it looks completely like trash to me and sometimes i can totally understand the value. i think when we think about value, i'm much more concerned about what's the value to the client that i'm working with, less about the finical value because we have people who hoard, you know the guy who has 15 or 20,0000 toothpaste caps, and for him they're extremely valuable, for me they would be trash. and so i think it's important that we as professionals are really careful about how we think about value.

Call: so, for you what's relevant really to telling if somebody has hoarding disorder is not what they're saving or how objectively valuable it is, more that their stuff is impairing their life. so, you could hoard valuable art and if your house was unusable, it would still be hoarding disorder.
Response: yeah, for the most part.

Call: yeah, for the most part.
Response: okay. another thing that has come out in these interviews has to do with the diagnostic criteria that reads, "the difficulty discarding results in the accumulation of possessions that congest and clutter active living areas and substantially compromises their intended use." and that seems to be what you're talking about in terms of the space kind of impairing the person's life. i'm wondering how you think about, and i'm sure this is something that you encounter, the fact that if you have less space, if you're living in a very small apartment for instance, it's much easier for your space to become congested and cluttered as opposed to somebody who lives in a huge mansion who has plenty of space, or somebody who can afford storage units. do you feel like it's easier for a person who has a small apartment to have hoarding disorder, or do you feel like that doesn't really play out that way?

Call: would it be hypothetically possible to hoard items that don't take up space, such as somebody who has like thousands of digital books on their computer and has no more hard drive space and can't use their computer because they have--you know, i guess what i'm asking about is does it have to be space in the home? is that a necessary part of it?
Response: you know, i think at least for right now, yes. you know, i could certainly see an argument about hoarding elsewhere, but that's where really the question becomes in what way is it impairing the individual's functioning in whatever part of their life? because without that impairment i don't really see how that's a disorder.

Call: so for you that comes back to impairment, and i guess when you're talking about impairment, how do you determine...so again, i could imagine a person making an argument that their kitchen use is not impaired because they don't cook, they don't use their stove, so the fact that they have huge piles of stuff on their stove isn't impairing to them because they would never use their stove anyway. so, when you're trying to determine if somebody is truly impaired, particularly in a disorder like this where people sometimes struggle with seeing the impairment, how do you make that determination?
Response: i think that's where we have to look at, you know, there are a lot of different kinds of impairment. so, if somebody's not cooking but they've still got items on their stove, that's a fire hazard that could impair their health and safety if there were to be a fire. so just given what we know about how long it takes to intervene in hoarding-related fires, and so i think that people with hoarding may look very narrowly at impairment, while we're looking much more broadly at is this impacting your ability to carry out daily life activities? is it impacting your ability to remain safely housed? is it impacting your health and wellbeing overall in ways that the person might not necessarily see, given the disabling nature of hoarding.

Call: and when you think about the individuals you've encountered with this disorder, do you feel like it's more connected to the reasons that they give for saving individual items? or do you feel like there's a component that is about how they like their space. so, maybe patients might describe their space as being cozy, or needing to feel enclosed by items. how do you feel about that?
Response: i think it depends on the person. we've heard both, sometimes in combination and sometimes not. and so i think it's tough because it's such an individualized set of reasons for why people save, right, and i think that that's part of the challenge. so, for some people it might be a feeling of safety, while for other people it might be more utilitarian.

Call: and when you talk to people and when you have talked to people about their reasons for this behavior, and this is totally subjective, this is 100% your opinion, do you feel like the reasons that people give for saving items are what's driving the behavior, or do you feel like the behavior comes first and then the person is kind of justifying the behavior by giving these reasons? does that make sense? is it more of an impulse that the person does, they save and then when you ask them why they give you a reason why? or is the reason really driving the behavior?
Response: you know, that's a good question and i actually don't feel like i know the answer.

Call: okay. um, so one of the difficulties with this disorder in the long literature, and i'm sure you encounter it in your work and in your life all the time, is the problem of insight and one of the diagnostic criteria reads, "the difficulty discarding is due to a perceived need to save items and to distress associated with discarding," and i'm wondering how you think about distress in this context, when people will often deny that they are distressed by kind of the state of their home and they may also deny that they would be distressed if they had to discard their items? so how do you think about that? how do you think about the way that that distress fits into this diagnosis?
Response: you know, when we're talking about most of our clients don't have a whole lot of insight, right, so they're like "no everything's fine." you know, what we often try to do is get them talking about the way the stuff isn't actually working for them, whether it's about housing or they can't find their remote or they're tripping. and so, for us often the distress is apparent even if it's not apparent to them and so a lot of time our work is really focused on how do we get them talking about the ways that maybe things aren't going as well as they are telling themselves they are because to some degree i think that saying that everything's really okay it's not a big deal is a great way to have to avoid the reality that maybe things actually aren't as good are they are, or as they seem. and so, i think that that for us a lot of times it's we see the distress and we see the impairment in functioning whether it's distress by the individual or someone else and so a lot of times for us it's really having the conversation and getting them to articulate how stuff's not working so well--even if we're doing it in a way that's not directly saying, "well i don't think this is working so well." it's really kind of saying, "you know it sounds like on the one hand stuff is feeling great, and on the other hand you lost your keys or you can't find your medication" or kind of tell them more about the ways this stuff isn't going the way you'd like it to.

Call: so it sounds like a major task for you, with a person with hoarding disorder, is helping them to experience or to see their own distress.
Response: yeah.

Call: so, kind of to turn the conversation towards that problem with insight, how do you define insight or low insight in this context? what does having insight mean for a person with hoarding disorder?
Response: you know like with everything else, i think that depends on the person. sometimes it can be understanding that they've got the problem and why that may be, sometimes significant change in insight for someone might be acknowledging that they can see why another person might see and issue, even if they are not ready to admit it but they're ready to do something to at least start making somebody else happy and then kind of finding their own ways. you know, so a lot of our work is getting people to go from "there's no problem, why is everybody picking on me?" to "okay well maybe there's an issue."

Call: so there was this interesting paper that randy frost published which broke the concept of insight down into different constructs, and i'd just like to read them to you and have you comment on how you encounter these different sorts of insight, if you think that some are more relevant than others? so the first one is defensiveness, the second one is anosognosia, which is where you're unable to even perceive your illness or that anything is wrong or causing you distress, the third one is overvalued ideation, and that's kind of believing that your items are more valuable than they truly are, and the last one is indifference. do any of these, all of these seem like they're relevant for your patients? is there one that you think is more important or less important?
Response: i certainly think the defensiveness is the one that resonates the most. that's something we just see day in and day out, even from folks that are willing to work with us and i think a lot of it seems to come from the fear that we're not gonna understand their stuff or value their stuff and that we're gonna judge them. they know that the system overall can be very punitive, and so what we find is once we make it clear that we're not gonna take their stuff because that's not our role, or tell them what to do, that they have control of their stuff no matter what, the defensiveness seems to break down. a lot of it really seems to be very fear-based.

Call: um, when you encounter people who have this disorder and have very low insight, would you say that they truly don't know that there's anything different about them or their lives than other people? that they're truly bling to the fact that they have something about them that's different? or is it more that they don't acknowledge that that difference is a problem?
Response: it feels like they know that not everybody else sees their stuff in their situation the way that they do, and aren't able to see the reasons that that might be a problem. i don't think it's willful disobedience or willful avoidance in most cases, but in some cases sometimes it might be. you know, i think a lot of it is all centered around perception and ability to kind of do the analysis that is required to have accurate perception.

Call: so would you say that when one of those individuals looks at their space, that they can't see how cluttered it is? that they see a normal space, even when it's clearly not normal?
Response: well normal for them at least. you know, i think they can't see the health and safety issues and the volume in the same way that the rest of us would see.

Call: and do you feel like that's just because they're so used to it or do you feel like that's almost in the level of like a delusion?
Response: i think it's hard for me to know sometimes. there are certainly some people where they just do not see it, and then there are some people where they might say, "oh it's a little bit messy but it's not that bad." as we're looking at something that's fairly severe. and so, you know, i generally don't think that it's avoidance as much as it is sometimes it feels like the brain's not giving them accurate data to work with.

Call: mhhm, and do you feel--i'm assuming that you've encountered also individuals that have problems with animal hoarding, because of your role. is that correct?
Response: right.

Call: do you feel like that's different for those individuals?
Response: you know, we don't have that many cases that come across every year so it's sort of hard to tell.

Call: okay.
Response: there's certainly a different level of attachment to the animals and an inability, when there's poor animal care, to be able to see it that feels a little bit different from object hoarding, but certainly that's not...again, we don't see that many so it's sort of hard for me to say.

Call: when you think about the individuals that you've encountered with this disorder, do you have any sense for how long the behavior's been going on before you see them?
Response: certainly for most of our folks, decades. you know, dating back to late teens, early twenties.

Call: and i guess just as you encounter these individuals, do you think that it's like a progressive illness that gets worse with age, or do you see it more as a set of circumstances? so like, as a person ages they naturally become more socially isolates, their children might leave home, they might inherit things from their parents, they might have a fixed income, and that those are the things that make it get worse as they get older?
Response: you know, we're not seeing people who are going out and actively acquiring all the time later in life, especially since they're frail, it feels like it's more of a, when you think about how much stuff builds up over a course of decades if you're not able to get rid of it, either through active acquiring or through things like junk mail that just come into our lives, it feels like it's more of a slow slide off of a slippery slope than anything else. it just kind of builds up and builds up and builds up.

Call: so, maybe it's more that the stuff has built up rather than the behavior has gotten recently worse?
Response: correct.

Response: 1:yeah. kids like to be empowered. i feel like theres almost two schools nowadays. the kids that have no power and the kids that have way too much power. theres not many of the in between kids. i feel like anybody who feels like theyre in a place where theyre needing therapy like this is your thing to do for yourself kind of type thing and makes it user friendly. again the parent its not a thing where you have to poke and nag because usually whatever is on their list is usually on yours including everything else. it really wasnt a burden other than me getting her here and paying for everything. again i think its just everybody really likes it, its convenient, you get fast results, its very empowering for your child or it was for us. it just seems effective and also another thing is that theres no side effects. i almost feel like there could be a parody video or comedy that would just probably be for me but like about how you know theres all these happy people and theyre like yes, yes and you might die and your skin may fall off and everythings burning but theres still 27% of people that do like everything is said with a smile on the face. sounds so great but really what theyre telling you is terrible. like this is not terrible. the risk that is involved in doing this method its like pretty low risk for pretty quick results.

Response: 1:i dont think so. i just wish that this was more available like just to the public in general. mental health has become such a big thing, especially with adolescence. like i have to go to trainings all the time about all these things and im in the front lines with peoples kids that are going through all kinds of crazy stuff all the time and its intense and i feel like we get a lot of feedback about our school like what are the resources? and some dont even know. its like theres too many options or not knowing who to ask the right questions. so of course im always like your pediatrician. its almost like an alternative therapy but once you say alternative therapy some people immediately think its like a chant in the woods or something type thing or youre going to sign up for this big weird thing so it would be great to have. i think its great what you guys are setting out to do and succeeded. people would watch a quick video that gave just enough information to be like oh, maybe this is something we could do.

Call: here we go. okay, so thank you for meeting with us today. so, as im asking you questions, its going to be about cognitive behavioral therapy which is the therapy that we do here. but cognitive behavioral therapy is a little bit of a mouthful so ill refer to it as cbt.
Response: okay.

Call: and you can refer to it as cbt if youd like. so to start, could you tell me what comes to mind when you think about cbt?
Response: basically just helping with whatever issues- i mean i think of specifically what NAME- you know just helping with the issues that she has.

Call: okay. when you say issues, generally what are you speaking of? could you elaborate a little bit?
Response: NAME has anxiety.

Call: okay.
Response: she has always been a... high anxiety child so. she has anxiety issues.

Call: okay. so could you tell me what you know about cbt in your own words? how would you explain what cbt is?
Response: that is not an easy one for me.

Call: the best you can do.
Response: talking, a lot of talking and discussing what is happening throughout life and how to work through whatever whatever issues have come up throughout life basically.

Call: okay. perfect. so when you first learned about the therapy we do here, cbt, do you remember any questions that you had about the process or just cbt in general?
Response: no. things had become so chaotic in our life at home. you know, we went to our pediatrician and just said please help and she said go here and we said okay.

Call: okay. did you know anything about cbt going in?
Response: no.

Call: no? okay. so how much did you know about cbt from movies, tv, the internet, or other people in general?
Response: nothing.

Call: nothing? okay so you didnt know anything. so thinking about your experience with cbt were there any parts of the therapy that were confusing or- yeah, that were confusing?
Response: no. you know, we didnt really have a lot of discussion about, you know, what was going to happen or- it was just everything had become so incredibly chaotic it was, something has to happen and something has to change. help us and the pediatrician said do this and we were doing this.

Call: okay. so if someone were to ask you about cbt, what would you want to tell them if they were about to start the therapy?
Response: for us, its been- for us specifically with NAME because we have- weve done it with NAME and, you know, weve got the younger ones in therapy now also for different reasons but for NAME its been extremely helpful. she obviously still has anxiety, i dont think thats something thats ever going to change. its just part of her personality and who she is. but we can talk her through panic attacks and calm her down just through talking and but having another outlet in a different person for her to talk to is absolutely a wonderful thing for her to have.

Call: okay. great. so when you think about how you felt about cbt when you first learned about it, can you think of three words to describe how you felt? i know it would be kind of a weird question but
Response: i didnt really know anything about it, at that point. so

Call: so when you first learned about it. after it was explained to you, did you have any thoughts in your mind about cbt? that could be in 3 words.
Response: i dont really know how to answer that because that was so  that was so long ago. im sorry.

Call: okay. thats okay. maybe well circle back around to that question. so the goal of cbt is to reduce anxiety so if someone asked you how anxiety becomes a problem in someones life, what would you say?
Response: i feel like for for us, i think a lot of NAME had to do with external factors i think its always, you know, there as a part of her personality but i think external factors exacerbate it. i think weve had a lot of family drama, which for her triggers that.

Call: so you would say family drama is one of your external factors?
Response: correct.

Call: okay. are there any other external factors that exacerbate her anxiety?
Response: school drama, which sadly being a teenage girl, is a factor of life.

Call: yup. okay. these are good examples. so what is important for other patients to know about how anxiety becomes an issue? so like you said external factors like school, family. what would be important for patients to know when starting cbt?
Response: it has to be a very honest process. thats one of the- thats one of the concerns i had with NAME, you know, because shes very reserved and closed off, is that she wouldnt be-she wouldnt give it a chance and really open up to anybody. so, it has to be a very honest process.

Call: so could you tell me if there is any specific skills or areas that cbt targets? it could be in your experience with your daughter.
Response: you know, i dont know because we dont- you know, NAME and i- we dont talk about her sessions. so she keeps that as her time for whatever she wants to discuss. i know she has been much more open and communicative with me since shes started therapy which... is a wonderful thing.

Call: okay. good. so, as a parent, what is your involvement with cbt with your daughter-daughters?
Response: well, i bring them obviously.

Call: yes.
Response: but, you know, if we have any big events that could trigger anxiety or that i think their therapist needs to know about, i will let their therapist know about those issues. but other than- other than that, thats their time to discuss what they need to discuss.

Call: for other parents, what would be useful for them to know when bringing their child in for cbt?
Response: i think that what i really liked was having that first initial meeting with the therapist to discuss overall, big picture what was going on. to kind of go over what the issues and kind of what the goals were. and check in periodically, especially when the life events happen.

Response: no.

Response: yeah i think that would be helpful. that would be good information to put out there.

Response: i have personally had therapy so

Call: oh okay.
Response: i know that its helpful.

Call: so you would say that its positive?
Response: yes.

Response: a parent, you know, like a parent-child relationship could be at home or even in a vehicle. i know a lot of parents, you know, thats where they spend a lot of time with their kids.

Call: in the car. going to school.
Response: in the cars. right.

Response: that i dont know. because i didnt know anything about it. it was just a last-ditch effort because NAME was a disaster. i i mean NAME was falling apart.

Response: that its definitely okay to get help and support. you know, i still think theres some sort of stigma attached with therapy and counseling for a lot of people which is ridiculous. not only that and you know i dont know maybe some of the benefits?

Call: alright, thanks so much for meeting with me today. i am with a group of clinical psychologists and psychiatrists working on a project to make videos about cognitive behavioral therapy which is the therapy thats done here at this clinic. so cognitive behavior therapy is a mouthful, so im going to refer to it as cbt throughout this interview and we just want to get your perspective and your general thoughts about the therapy. so to start, could you tell me what comes to mind when you think of or hear cbt?
Response: cbt? um well it is a technique used for the treatment of variety psychiatric psychological disorders where you try to use graded graded and guided approaches to modify the responses and the anxiety associated with particular types of responses often through exposure or other sorts of i guess controlled environments and providing a safe environment for individuals toi guess uh become cognitively aware of their physiological responses to adverse stimuli that cause them anxiety or distress.

Call: so that sounds like theres, to sum everything up, it sounds like there are a lot of skills that are learned in cbt and that these are things are used to challenge anxiety.
Response: well i think i mean i think the goal of it is to ultimately give individual i guess tools whether theyre behavioral tools to help deal with you know whatever their adverse reactions are or their anxieties to teach them approaches and method that will work for them when they are not there. so i think there are combinations of both you know guided exposures, but then also demonstrating how they can utilize those in the future.  ___ it can be used alone or in combination withyou know pharmacological therapy.

Call: 03: 58it sounds like yeah a lot of ways and techniques that you can combat anxiety with cbt. so speaking of anxiety, one of the major goals of cognitive behavior therapy is to kind of challenge anxiety. in your own words, if someone were to ask you how anxiety becomes problematic in someones life, how would you response? what would your explanation of that be?
Response: well i think anxiety if it leads to an adverse effect on your welfare whether that yours ability to function in school or in work or their home life or in their relationships then i would say that the anxiety is of you know concern. i think that can be difficult to define. how does anxiety specifically lead to adverse effects? i think that it depends on the different type of anxiety and what they and what their specifically concerned about  _____ it sort of depends on, but overall how it affects the individual and their function.

Call: could you give me some examples of potentially how because i know you mention that it does varies on the anxiety. what are some ways you think that could look like?
Response: social anxiety if you are anxious about social interaction it could lead you to avoid situations where you are going to have to interact with individuals and so that could make it difficult for you at work or more extreme cases. you know not being able to carry out normal daily functions. so i think those are one type of anxiety.

Call: sounds like it affects multiple things. you are mentioning work, school, and relationships.
Response: mmhm yeah yeah. i mean it can manifest primarily in one or the other.

Call: thats where you say it varies based upon the person really.
Response: i think also anxiety can often contribute to other psychiatric disorders like depression. it could coincident with other disorders exacerbate their manifestations.

Call: so in your experience as a parent of a child who has gone through cbt, what was that experience like for you?
Response: 07: 34well i mean i think overall its helpful in terms of you know providing  __  i dont know. i guess for me i not really involved in the day to day. i only see the outcome. i would say at least for my older son certainly definitely seemed to help him and you know dealing with school and performance anxiety, you know those issues. so i think it has been positive for him. i think it has helped him gain perspective on what is going on. i think it helped to destigmatize it to a certain extent. i think it made him more self-aware of the issues and you know helped him deal with it so i think that there is some partial possible benefits.  so for me i guess it has been helpful. you know because of patient confidentiality you dont really have much insight to what is actually happening on a day to day bases. somewhat dependent on what the child tells you which so i dont have a good sense of what the individual activities he did or what you know i have some sense they were essentially trying to you know throw curveballs and sort of disrupt you know such  ___  still function in a chaotic environment. i think there was an attempt to make it fun and enjoyable, not stressful. so i think that was maybe something that i thought was i kind of had a maybe bias that you know essentially it was more of a graded response and that you kind of helped people get over their level of anxiety with elicited.  i dont know i think i had an unpleasant association sort of with that idea that you would be sort of stressing them, and i think thats what was most surprising to me was that it was not as stressful as um. that my son actually seemed to enjoy it and look forward to it, rather than being negative as something to get through. that was definitely not unexpected sort of so.

Call: in what ways was that unexpected umm, like in what ways was that unexpected for you? it sounds like there was a different preconception kind of going in to thinking what it would look like.
Response: i think that my preconception is essentially stress them out until the anxiety subsides and that they dont you know thats a difficult process because you have induce the anxiety in order to show thats its not going to cause harm or the adverse  ___ are anticipated are not actually going to happen, and to me that worries me from what i think. from what i heard there was a lot of humor, a lot of ways to sort of deescalate the situation and made it a less unpleasant situation than i would have expected.

Call: is that kind of the knowledge you acquired about it there being more perhaps to cbt than just the kind of like the mechanism side of things. is that something that would be important for other parents to know if they are contemplating whether or not to have their child go through cbt?
Response: when you say the mechanisms, do you mean like neurochemical reprogramming or do you mean the mechanisms in terms of what actually happens in cbt?

Call: i think more the latter where in terms of you expose yourself to a stimulus to induce anxiety and then learn that the feared outcome is not actually happening, but you mention that also there seems to be some fun involved and there were other things that made it..
Response: yeah i think that would be helpful.  i mean i think that would also depend on the skill of the practitioner. unrelated thing, my older son wasnt treated here a long time ago you know had a run with cbt and it worked. it was more difficult for him. so i think it sort of depends on it can be dependent on the skill of the practitioner or it may also be dependent on the individual child and how difficult it is to them to deal with so. yeah, but i think understanding that it is not going to solely an unpleasant experience both for the child and the parent. i think it is helpful. although again, i think there has to be some realistic expectations, and i mean i guess it also depends on the cbt whether how much they are going to have an expectation that the parent is going to be involved. i think often therapy is relatively limited and you are going to have to have more outside parental involvement. so i think that can be challenging for parents. it can be difficult to them to put their child in that situation. it is unpleasant for them. so um yeah it goes against sort of your parental instincts. so i think that can be a challenge that kind of needs to be made clear to parents. that sometimes you are going to be asked or told to do things that are not what you would think, you know. protecting your child is not always the best way to move forward. i mean i guess the other thing is consistency. and um yeah providing consistency because i think thats important and i think thats really hard, especially when you are dealing with two different parents. i dont know. i think thats getting off topic i think yeah its obviously very helpful to have parents understand what the processes as well as the child. what are the things that they are going to have to confront as they go forward and i dont know?

Call: well what would you are some of those things that they would have to confront? like what you were giving some good advice to kind of parent in terms of what to expect, but are there any sorts of specific types of things youd say would be really useful kind of like as heads-up when some is first entering therapy, like what they should know of in order to be successful.
Response: well i think that the point about that you are going to the therapy may contradict your parental instincts. i think thats important for parents to know. yeah i mean i think you would have to be able to sit also with your childs anxiety as well i guess which is similar to that. i think that its helpful to know that it will work, you know and i think .  i think having something about that it at least for some cases it, it is most effective therapy. what else, umm yeah its not going to be always unpleasant. thats the other thing is sort of the kids are quite are happy too, and they make progress. so i think thats in some cases true, depends on the child i guess. umm yeah i dont know. thats everything i would probably say.

Call: ok. are there things you wish you knew of that either it took time for you to learn or you still may not know the answer to?
Response: well i think one of the things is that its not like a once and done sort of thing. thats its an ongoing process. that even though you may deal with one particular anxiety that you know a very similar patters can arise in other so its you know there could a whack-a-mole sense sometimes so its not like they are going to come in and get the course of cbt and they are going to get cured and their lives are going to be perfect from then on. so i think that its an ongoing process that and that you may need to come back for a tune up or whatever you deal with that. so i think understanding that its an ongoing process and you know yeah and that it will require active participation on the part of the parents. its not something like you just say here take care of my kid. its not how it works. its more like a partnership.  i think kind of explaining that and sort of the expectations of the parents. it not like even with drugs i mean its not like ok here. i think the other things is that its not an either or choice.  i think a lot of people parents sort of have this preconception thats it either drugs or cbt and its not. its doesnt need to be an either or. i mean i dont know the statistics on how often it is combined but you know so i think thats important to know as well as. this is a part of

Call: 5 to 10 minutes at most.
Response: ok not along, bye

Call: so thats actually a... well another question i had about this side of topics if you had to describe cbt in three words, how would you describe it?
Response: cbt in three words.

Call: without saying cbt. or maybe three alternatively three words that come to mind in general when thinking about it.
Response: controlled exposure to reduce anxiety. thats more than three. controlled exposures or anxiety.

Call: okay. so very much about the exposure side in terms of dealing with anxiety. its kind of the big thing that comes to mind when you think about it.
Response: it is yeah. i mean i know thats a component of it.

Call: ok um so i want to transition a little bit as i said at the beginning were making some videos. a lot of these questions are meant to guide the creation of the videos, but more explicitly i wanted to ask you know these videos were meant to be for the general audience we potentially may have parental videos and then kid videos or it may just be that theyre both um, but from your perspective who do you think should be in these videos? like what type of characters should be included?
Response: what type of character?

Call: right so you know and thinking about this should there be non-human characters and animals. should there be
Response: no i dont, no. i think it depends on your audience. for young children maybe you know. animation or whatever, but for anybody 12 or older i would think that most compelling is going to be individuals who have gone through it talk about their experiences or whatever. that would be my thought

Call: ok, so people who have gone through it. so like patients it sounds like. patients who have experienced this.
Response: mmhmm, yeah.

Call: how would you feel about doctors or therapist treating them? would you also include them in these videos?
Response: yeah, i think so. i mean i think i would not start with therapist. i would start with patients and their parents.

Call: so parents are important too.
Response: if its appropriate for age. i mean i guess that questions what age you are talking about.

Call: so i think just for some information its meant to be designed for 10 to 16 year olds which is arrange because obviously 10 year olds differ a lot from 16 year olds and there also the parents on top of it.
Response: yeah i would just make sure to have an age range of kids. i would start with the kids and their experience and then i would only you know i guess it depends on who you are trying to convince. if you are trying to bring in kids then i would have them talk about their experiences first.

Call: for the parental side, what do you think would be best for like a parent?
Response: i think yeah seeing kids and other parents is good.  ___ parental experience in there as well.

Call: in terms of setting, is there anything in particular that kind of stands out as a setting for the video to take place in?
Response: um well i would say more.  i would personally think it would be better if it were an individuals home rather than clinical settings or yeah that would be my thought. i dont know. im not sure i would think of

Call: im curious can you tell me why you lean towards like the home as opposed to a medical office or to a doctors office.
Response: well 99% of your time you are in the home. 99% of the time you are dealing with issues there.  ___ and your looking how is your life going to be outside of there you know.  i think its maybe appropriate when you are talking to a clinician or whoever and say ok you know these are tools we used, these are the things we do, or whatever. we have that in a clinical setting, but i think putting people in a clinical setting turns them into patients rather than people. so i think if you want to appeal to people put in a home setting, not a clinical setting.

Call: its not medicalized
Response: yup. they are not patients. they are people.

Call: in that line uh kids especially are spending a lot of time in school. how would you feel like school being in the background?
Response: i mean school would be an appropriate environment. i think sometimes though these... i think it would need to be dependent on what the specific anxiety is or specific issue that they are dealing with. i dont think especially that age, i dont know. middle school for sure. im not sure.  i mean i think are less likely to be open about their issues that they are dealing with so. i think it can even be anxiety producing for some individuals. i think you know to some extent it would helpful to have it in a safe at least or what would be perceived as a safe environment for children.

Call: ok. um looking at the subject matter what they will be talking about. what do you think will be the most impactful subject in terms of what type of things will be spoken in the video?
Response: i dont know. i mean i think it will be important to have a range of issues and different types of issues and different  ___.  and i think that it is important to have arc and kind of showing how individuals sort of are able to progress and you know how they felt before, where theyre going, and you know how they felt about the process along the way. so i think those are important. i dont know how much time you have umm yeah. so i think a variety of ages. i think you know things that are you know i would have a range of concerns from common to quite unusual.

Call: so it sounds like there should be breathe in terms of whats spoken about and also like as you mentioned arc, more of a story rather than just information being thrown kind of at the viewer. thats what im hearing.
Response: yeah i think an arc is helpful because at least it says ok you know it doesnt necessarily have to be a completed arc and i think in some ways that often would be important not say this is done, but ok this is what it was like before. it was really difficult. this is what we did, you know. this is how the parents helped and dealt with it. this is where we are know, you know. go forward from here whatever. so not i think thats helpful right i mean because. i think if you just talk about the process and not show what the outcomes are it wont be very helpful.

Call: 30: 31im transcribing so its fine.
Response: okay.

Call: or our ras are transcribing so
Response: so...

Response: yeah i think not detailed you know, but i think sort of. you know illustrations on how anxiety levels go up and then repeated exposures can decrease. i think things like that are helpful kind of just explain to them what the overall theories and ideas are. i think that would be helpful to give them some, you know idea what the process is and what to expect, you know.

Call: and um in...
Response: and that everything is going to be different depending on the individuals and anxiety.

Response: interesting. i dont know i mean i guess im. i dont know. i guess im not necessarily overly excited about the idea of um i dont know potentially maybe the vector art. i dont know i guess im just i can understand that. i just dont understand why you need the other things rather than just having individuals, children talk about it.

Call: so it sounds like more of just kind of like doing general filming without having special effects. do you think its sufficient?
Response: i dont know. it certainly would be my preference.

Call: it would be your preference. okay.
Response: i mean if im looking at stuff. i think i just fine it. i dont know distracting.

Response: well i think the thing to take home is that it works and that it takes time. you are not going to lose anything from trying. it is a collaboration between individual and parents and the you know the therapist. its not going to work out without all three being involved.
