Response: i dont think im an average... i dont think im uh i think i have a larger role. i may know more than what most parents will know so i think that i have a skewed perspective.

Call: thanks so much for meeting with me today. im part of research team thats looking at cognitive behavioral therapy, its the therapy that we do here at this clinic. with this project, we want to create some short educational videos talking about cognitive behavioral therapy. cognitive behavioral therapy is a mouthful, so im just going to refer to it as cbt throughout the video. okay? so lets start. can you just kind of tell me what goes through your mind when you think about cbt?
Response: sorry we were joking about the stuff they sell at the gas station so helping people to learn to recognize wrong thinking or learning in a way to manage the way you think.

Call: so learning ways to manage how you think. so it sounds like theres definitely a lot of a lot of it is about thoughts, would you say?
Response: yes. i would say yes.

Call: when you first learned about the kind of therapy we do here, did you have any questions about what it looked like?
Response: i did not. i mean i had heard of it before.

Call: okay. from where had you heard it from before?
Response: when i first started hearing about it, it was after the gulf war. it developed as a way to kind of help you deal with stress after post-traumatic stress and such. ive known others who have kind of used it as a way of therapy.

Call: okay, so have you had conversations with other people about cbt?
Response: a little bit, yes.

Call: what information from them did you receive, about this treatment?
Response: not a whole lot other than the basic idea that its kind of helping a person recognize maybe when theyre not thinking correctly or helping recognizing experiencing symptoms that may be not quite right, like anxiety- you learn to recognize the symptoms of anxiety and learn how to manage those a little better.

Call: if someone were to ask you how anxiety becomes a problem in someones life, how would you respond to that, from what youve learned from this process?
Response: high levels of anxiety can definitely hinder your ability to interact with others, or maybe overreact to help what people say to you. so it can definitely hinder your ability to fully function.

Call: what do you think is important for other patients to know about cbt?
Response: its not painful.

Call: can you elaborate more on that?
Response: im not super familiar on how the therapy goes on that, but what i understand is it is something that will help you to understand yourself better.

Call: so are you saying youre not as familiar with maybe the mechanisms?
Response: yeah, im not really familiar with the mechanisms of how its done.

Call: right. are there things you wish you knew, like in terms of how cbt operates, do you wish you had more knowledge on that?
Response: i guess so, yeah. it would probably be useful if i knew more about how it works. maybe how a typical session might run.

Call: okay so like the structure of a normal session, of what that looks like. you think that would be useful information for other people to see as well?
Response: :i do.

Call: what would you want to tell someone whos just starting cbt? is there any piece of advice you would give them, whether it be someone whos going in themselves or well just start with that- someone going in for themselves.
Response: i definitely believe mental health is very important, just generally. if you were sick, physically sick, i mean you wouldnt think much about going to the doctor, and they give you something to try- i mean we would try pretty much anything that they would suggest if we thought it would help. so cbt, from what i understand is something that has been successful. you know, people have had success in improving their mental health, so i would highly recommend trying it.

Call: in terms of youve heard its successful, have you encountered anything from a scientific perspective? have you encountered scientific articles or anything like that?
Response: no, i have not. nothing deeply scientifical.

Call: what would you want to tell parents, like if there was a parent of a child who was going to go into cbt? what would you want them to know?
Response: i would think for me as a parent, sometimes its a little hard for me to understand what exactly is going on in the therapy, and i think sometimes you expect not expect i mean you could have really fast results, but i think you have to understand theres a gradual process that does take time to go through, for a patient to work through.

Call: so its not necessarily an instant thing? as nice as that would be?
Response: right. it would be nice. i dont know if adults, but it was proved that kids, it seems takes a while for kids to kind of get that relationship with a therapist. it would be nice if we were all really truthful when we went to the doctor. that was one of my favorite shows that i used to watch was doctor house. everybody lies- i hope thats not true. i suspect for kids maybe its not that easy to be fully truthful in the beginning.

Call: if you had to think of or say three words that describe cbt to you, or three words that come to you head when you think of cbt, what would those words be?
Response: three words, okay. so itd be like develop better habits.

Call: ____ talked about earlier how youre identifying things that may not be the most useful for yourself
Response: yeah.

Call: going briefly back to other people, i know that you said you know other people that have gone through cbt. do you know if their experience was a positive one? negative?
Response: i know one person who tried it, and he didnt really give it enough time. it was a relative, and it was pretty exciting when i heard about it, but it was something that he didnt try for very long. these things take time.

Call: yeah thats kind of going with what you said earlier, right? its not necessarily a quick fix. its going to take some time.
Response: yeah. probably not going in once and done kind of a thing.

Call: right, definitely. could you tell me a little bit about the... you touched on this a little briefly about challenging negative thoughts what are some other areas that cbt targets? what skills do you develop from it?
Response: not just challenging negative thoughts, but also, i think was part of it, recognizing maybe when you are more, i think anxiety when you are feeling moments of anxiety, if you can recognize that, then you can draw from things you learned in cbt to help you manage it better.

Call: so a little bit like a toolkit.
Response: yeah, yeah. or almost like exercising a little bit, build up your strength.

Call: right. what was the role of feelings in cbt, would you say?
Response: feelings, emotions i dont know im not sure about that.

Call: how about like behaviors or actions?
Response: behaviors is probably more like to, you react- you behave in a certain way. maybe youre in a crowd and you dont want to participate or whatever the situation is, maybe in that type of therapy you might learn to recognize that those situations are not recognize whats happening in the situation and realize its something you can improve or change.

Call: cool. awesome. so im just going to turn to more of the video side of things. so thinking about these videos theres kind of a twofold thing, where on one hand they want to make videos for kids, but were also contemplating the use of creating videos for parents. so when you answer these questions, feel free to think about both sides of things, like what you think would be useful. so, first in terms of the who: if were making videos like this, who do you think should be starring in these videos?
Response: who would be starring in the videos lets see i see a lot of those animals here. i never thought about that. we tend to see things like putting famous people on lately and doing little video bits that you see on tv for mental health spokespersons. sometimes i think that helps because it helps bring those topics out and make them seem a little more normal. ive also seen videos where they use maybe people who had gone through the therapy, and as a result of that had improved. those were also good so they can explain how it helped them. i dont know if youre thinking about live action videos

Call: yeah, yeah! its something well get to.
Response: yeah or animation or cartoons is what we started on here, and so maybe different as an adult, id probably relate to the non-cartoons better, but id think children could relate to better to something like a cartoon.

Call: looking at the characters, so what would you say would be important for the parent? ____
Response: from a parent, were looking for answers. were looking for ways to help our children. and from a parents perspective, a video, they might relate more to adult type characters, and maybe theyll relate to how theyll help their family or help them.

Call: how would you feel about there being doctors, for instance?
Response: doctors i dont know thats a good question on that. im used to seeing on tv you know, those tv doctors that are usually not real, so im not sure if id relate well to that or not. i would probably relate more if it was like a parent or somebody from that level, someone more relatable.

Call: that makes sense. so transitioning a little bit to the setting, what would be some good settings that we could have the video in?
Response: i guess maybe more of a reenactment. maybe you might start with a scene where somebody is encountering some kind of mental health challenge, and maybe thats the starting point so you can identify what type of challenges people would have and then transition into entering therapy. i dont know how long this video is going to be transitioning into what kind of benefits you can bring through therapy or cbt and then finally having the final result of the miraculous cure- something to see the benefit out of it.

Call: sounds like showing the whole process- the problem to how it gets resolved.
Response: right. so maybe in the beginning you might relate to the person youre watching because youre saying, okay i can relate to that scenario. then maybe understand a little bit about how the process helped. you probably want to do this in like 30 seconds, right?

Call: that, were still deciding.
Response: our attention span probably isnt that long.

Call: well i guess from your perspective, how long do you think a video like this would be, like at what point are you saying, this is too long.
Response: i was thinking about that. its almost like youd want a short part of it to get peoples attention then maybe break off into a more detailed discussion. could almost see that, like theres some kind of carton video then it breaks off into the doctor coming in talking a little bit about what is happening, what the benefits would be, then maybe back into a video might help to at least get somebodys attention in the beginning.

Call: so multi-segmented, perhaps? help them pay attention.
Response: yeah, yeah.

Call: just in terms of specific locations, would you think that showing things at home would be relevant or important?
Response: yeah theres a lot of possible scenarios for kids. theres school where youre maybe having peer pressures that you encounter, and of course home life is always a challenge for us all, isnt it? so, because theres so many things you could treat with cbt, im not quite sure itd be hard to pick one.

Call: what about like the therapists office?
Response: therapists office probably could, just to get people you know, when i grew up, when i was a kid someone going to the therapists office was kind of stigmatizing. at least from my perspective, im past that, but maybe not everybody is.

Call: how would you address the issue of stigma, especially for parents who are from an era where, as you said, it was more stigmatized?
Response: people like my age, im talking to my parents, that age particularly, their response now is, we wish we knew those things back then. their main response is, we didnt even know there was options out there for improving mental health.  i think its important if youre looking at it as being something more stigmatizing now or you dont want your neighbors to know that youre going, years later its definitely something youd look back on and say, i wish i had taken those steps at that time.

Call: so sounds like growing up  ___ the opportunity is valuable.
Response: right. so you may not recognize it on the front end, but you will definitely see it on the back end.

Call: so we touched a little bit on this piece, about what they should talk about, but like further going into that, what types of questions should be asked or answers should be had?
Response: somebody whos looking at this hmm im not sure about that. id say im not sure about that.

Call: should there be an explanation perhaps of how anxiety becomes a problem? is that something that would be useful?
Response: yeah i think or that theres help out there to improve those things. its not something that you should just its not necessarily something that you can just deal with on your own. you might need some help.

Call: so like recognizing it as an issue.
Response: right, like if you want to be a professional football player, youre probably going to recognize you need training, you need coaches; theres a lot of things you can do that can help you. maybe theres some analogy there too you know, its like in therapy can help you theres somebody there you can definitely improve what youre doing. theres definitely probably more sports analogies you can give for kids, there might be other analogies kids or parents could relate to that scenario where you wouldnt think twice about getting help. if i wanted to learn tennis i would certainly want to hire a teacher rather than sit out there by myself trying to figure it out. so, in this case here, going into a therapist or somebody who can help you figure these things out a lot easier than trial and error.

Call: right, right. how about discussing how its worked for others? i think you kind of mentioned that a little bit earlier. at least in your opinion, you saw that its been effective. do you think thats worth discussing?
Response: yeah, yeah. i think its been effective, just kind of watching it in my family, and yeah- i think so. when it came out that was the big excitement, cbt- there was a method that could perhaps give a lot faster improvements than the other forms of therapy did before that. that was the appeal i heard about originally, wow, theres something that actually might have noticeable benefits that doesnt take 10 years of laying on a couch, and theres no laying on a couch, as far as i know, too.

Call: should there be discussion about exposures and how they work?
Response: yeah, i think so. i think its something people can quickly understand how that would work, like youre having trouble with something- i talk about anxieties, thats one im more familiar with- and the idea of exposing yourself gradually to that. eventually you can be exposed to higher and higher levels.

Call: what about from a parent perspective? what types of things should be discussed on what is helpful for parents to do versus whats not helpful for parents to do?
Response: i had this discussion before with a therapist, and myself as a parent kind of frustrated like, i dont know what to do, is where a kind of found myself is like yeah, i want to help my children, but i cant figure out how to do it, and the one answer i got back that i liked was, coming here, that was a good idea. you find yourself maybe not theres help out there, lets put it that way. definitely you want to be involved as a parent. you dont just want to drop your kids off and pick them up at the end of therapy.

Call: so it sounds like involvements important, actually being a figure and being a part of the team.
Response: yeah, yeah.

Call: awesome. so moving on to how its going to look, so were still toying with the idea. we do have this right here has 3 different options of potential kind of  ___. so you can take a second and well go over that, and im just curious of what your impressions of those 3 options are, like if theres one that particularly stands out to you or you really hate one. there arent necessarily the only things. these are heavy contenders, basically.
Response: yeah, yeah, not sure quite what i get from the one in the middle. kind of getting this idea of something kind of beyond whats inside of you. you want to think about too much math on the right. the one in the middle is a little cleaner i guess is kind of my first thought looking at it. the one on the left has got a lot going on there in terms of the picture.

Call: _____ variation on the line art side of things.
Response: right, on the side of it on that, the people are all about the same

Call: how about on the second page i think transitions a little bit more to a cartoony style.   ___ kids, but what are your thoughts kind of on that style?
Response: i dont know, im kind of big on the carton. maybe the one in the middle. maybe part of it is its easier to relate yourself to a cartoon than it is to its hard to get a generic looking person. its a little harder to relate to a person when youre looking at a picture. the cartoons, i think, have the advantage  ____

Call: right. how about for like a parent video? how do you feel about doing a cartoony style like option 2?
Response: parents are different, right. for me, i grew up watching cartoons saturday morning, so that was also my perspective on it, and i watch a few more now because theyre a little more mainstream, but um, i think they could relate.

Call: again, i just wanted to thank you for participating in the research, and thank you for being with us today. of course, you know what the cartoons study is about. basically, we are creating educational videos describing what cognitive behavioral therapy is, its the kind of therapy that your child is receiving here, and cognitive behavioral therapy is so long, its such a tongue twister to really say, were going to be saying cbt, just to help out real quick with that. so to start out, please tell me what comes to mind when you first think about cbt? theres no right answer.
Response: as the parent of the child in it?

Call: yeah, from your perspective. from what you know. im sure youve sat in on some sessions or he has homework and stuff like that, so just tell us, from your perspective, theres no right or wrong answer, what you think cbt is.
Response: having help from somebody else to work through whatever issues youre facing.

Call: when you sat in on the session, do you remember a time where you were explained to exactly what the treatment would look like or anything like that with cbt?
Response: well, what goals they were going to work on, yes, not really in what way.

Call: okay. could you tell me what you know about cbt in your own words, how would you explain what cbt is, if someone were to ask you?
Response: i dont know a lot of specifics. its just good to have a professional, someone whos not directly involved in the situation. they tend to give more worth to somebody elses opinion, the child does, versus just mom or dad telling them what to do.

Call: when you first learned about the kind of therapy we do here, do you remember what questions you had for the therapist?
Response: not really. we had an experience previously where he basically refused to even speak. so it was like, how was that going to work? how do you handle that?

Call: how do you handle a child not speaking?
Response: yes. hes literally spent lots of sessions not saying a word.

Call: okay. so that was a question that you had.
Response: yes, like how do you handle that? here, i didnt have anything specific.

Call: other than that, that was the major question, but other than that, you didnt have any other questions?
Response: yep.

Call: okay. what did you want to know about cbt when you first started sessions here?
Response: i cant think of anything specific, just how it will happen, how we can help him, what to work on each week.

Call: how much did you know about cbt from movies, tv, the internet, or other people before coming here?
Response: therapy in general.

Call: tell me more.
Response: just experience- his older brother is autistic and has generalized anxiety so were going through that with him, as well as group therapy for social skills training. my mother went to therapy for years, decades, so i just grew to her experience. i didnt really have any expectations, just getting help.

Call: did all or any of your experiences, or what you knew about cbt match your experiences here?
Response: yeah.

Call: how so?
Response: its been going well for him, definitely making progress. one step at a time.

Call: thinking about your experience, were there any parts of therapy that were confusing?
Response: i wouldnt say so, no. its made sense. it can be slow going, obviously, but thats to be expected.

Call: what would you want to tell someone whos about to start cbt?
Response: stick with it. itll take time. you get out of it what you put into it- which is what i work with him on, because if hes not saying a word then its just a waste of time. so yeah, just stick with it, youll see improvement, and you need to participate to help it work.

Call: think of 3 words that describe how you felt about cbt when you first learned about it. what would those words be?
Response: hope. progress. work.

Call: hope, progress, and work.
Response: you got to work at it.

Call: okay. if you were to add a picture to each of these words: hope, progress, and work, if you were to add a picture to each of these words, what would it be?
Response: work i guess would just be like a notebook or something, like just thoughts journaling. progress just like a graphic that i would attach to it?

Call: mhm.
Response: like a reward, like a ribbon or something reaching goals. hope sun? something to look forward to. happy.

Call: so you ___ the sun with happiness?
Response: yeah. bright.

Call: okay so tell me a bit about why you chose each picture with each word. so you had journaling for work. so what was that for?
Response: the thought that has to go into it. the whole thing of youre going to get out of it what you put into it.  ____ the progress for him, we break down the small goals and reward him as he reaches them. so its sort of like a ribbon, a generic, he doesnt get a ribbon, but its kind of like a generic thing for meeting a goal. then the hope i guess was just something kind of seen as positive or happy- the sun or smiley face or something.

Call: sounds good. the goal of cbt is to reduce anxiety overall, and if someone were to ask you how anxiety becomes a problem in someones life, what would you say?
Response: even when things are going well, their anxiety can mess it up. my eldest child says that hes stressed when hes not stressed, because he thinks he should be. like if things are going well, hes worried hes missed something. yeah, so when things are going well or going right, then theyre anxious that theres something else that theyre missing.

Call: so based off that, what do you think is important for other patients to know about anxiety and cbt?
Response: just in general that it can be all encompassing, that it takes commitment, time. its not just a cure and it goes away. you learn coping strategies and you still work on it.

Call: could you tell me if there are any specific skills or areas that cbt targets?
Response: not specifically that i know of, i can make a guess.

Call: try your best.
Response: we talk a lot about taking the hardship of it, being involved in it himself. ____ phase hardship a lot.

Call: what about thoughts? or feelings or actions? do you feel that cbt targets this area? how you heard anything about that in sessions?
Response: they bring me in at the end, and sometimes he has something to say specifically. ___ that its hard to address something, if we can put it into words, talking through it all.

Call: are there any questions that you wish youd asked before you started the cbt sessions?
Response: not that i can think of. not that i remember.

Call: what was your involvement in cbt? so, what does your involvement look like within the sessions when you come in here?
Response: he goes pretty much weekly. depending on his session, they want us both there first. sometimes its just him then they bring me in for my view as well. sometimes it matches, sometimes it does not. so they want to make sure were on the same track. we review what they had been working on for the week. they give him homework, tasks to complete. just being a part of that, one, because i can give input to how  ____ and two, im hearing about what theyre saying. otherwise, he just leaves and he says he doesnt know.

Call: so its helpful, sounds like.
Response: yes. because then i can say, well what did they same about that? and he can remember what she said, because i heard it too. its not bad. its just being a tween child and some of it is that theres a lot of information to take in.

Call: so, knowing that, what do you think would be useful for other parents to know, from your experiences?
Response: just making sure that youre open about it all. put your cards on the table kind of thing. if they dont have the whole picture, its hard to make any progress.

Call: so what do you think parents also need to know about sessions and how they work and
Response: that you will be involved with it as well, its not just your child; its a team effort.

Call: thats good. have you ever read or heard about any scientific research about cbt?
Response: not that i can think of.

Call: okay so if not, do you believe its something we should talk about in the videos that we are going to be constructing?
Response: probably. i mean, is it geared toward the parent or the child or both?

Call: i believe it will be geared towards both.
not really sure how it will turn out, but just based off of you
Response: just major statistics or something that benefit just to show theres science behind it the reason why you should participate.

Call: good to know. did you know about somebody elses experience with cbt prior to sessions here?
Response: prior to sessions here, yeah, my oldest child.

Call: okay so your oldest child had cbt, that was the approach used with your oldest child?
Response: one of them.

Call: okay. was it a positive or negative experience overall?
Response: it was positive.

Call: based off of that what do you think would be useful to know, based off your previous experience with one of your children?
Response: just that there is hope in it, and that you can get help through it, that theyll help you work through it one step at a time.

Call: seeing that were talking about creating educational videos, well first before i even show you the different layouts we have of different themes, we wanted to know, based off your thoughts or opinions, we need to decide who will be in the videos. so what characters do you think we should include in the videos? should there be any nonhuman characters such as animals, superheroes, or even children? should we include a boy or girl? so, just getting a good handle of what you believe, as far as character wise, of what should be in the videos.
Response: i would stick with people versus animals or characters.

Call: okay so superheroes would be.? is that people?
Response: i would just do regular people. personally, but im not a professional so i dont know.

Call: no its all about your we just want to gather information so theres no right or wrong answer.
Response: just people. anybody can relate to people.

Call: people. okay so when you say people, are we talking about children, parents, friends, doctors?
Response: yeah, like the doctor, the parents, the patient itself- the child.

Call: okay so youre thinking patient, doctor, parents, and families.
Response: yeah the office and staff.

Call: should we include a boy or girl? both?
Response: either. both.

Call: either/ or okay. so now that we have an idea of the characters youd want and some of the videos wed develop, we need to decide where they talk, so what kind of setting? would it be home or school, doctors office kind of setting, or maybe outside at the park? which one of those do you think? or maybe a combination of those?
Response: i would say probably home and office.

Call: home and office. the doctors office?
Response: depending upon the part or what viewpoint is coming across. like, whatever setting it happens in.

Call: okay, and why is that that youre thinking of the home and doctors office?
Response: just because thats where it typically would be discussed in the first place.

Call: okay. so its familiar is what youre saying?
Response: yes, like a doctor sent us to therapy, or we talked about it at home as a family. a type of setting that its already in.

Call: gotcha. alright, so now that we know the who and the where, lets talk about what, like what should they talk about? so what questions about cbt, we kind of already talked about this, if you had any questions, but if you could think of anything for the videos, what questions about cbt do you think the characters need to ask and/ or answer within the video?
Response: well depending on how young the audience is  ____, if its going to hurt; if its anything physical, because when you think of a doctor, you think more of a regular, general doctor. how long something might take. how long the session might be. just about the confidentiality part- that its a safe place to say anything. i cant think of anything else.

Call: so do you think we should include how cbt, the explanation of how anxiety can become a problem in someones life, and do you think that should be discussed in the video as well?
Response: yeah. the why, the general why you should go to  ___ how it can help, yes.

Call: okay. should we ask how it has worked for other kids?
Response: if it has worked?

Call: yeah. how or if it has worked for other kids.
Response: yeah.

Call: should we ask about how exposures work?
Response: maybe? in the first video?  _____

Call: theres no right or wrong answer its based upon parents perspective. what you feel you wouldve wanted to see.
Response: probably not initially.

Call: not initially. okay. should we ask about what parents can or cant do to help?
Response: yes. definitely.

Call: why would you say definitely?
Response: because thats always helpful. suggestions and expectations.

Call: good to know. so now were going to talk about the how. so how the video will look like. we have 3 options of artistic styles. 1 being the line art option, 2 being vector art, and 3 being the comic art blended with live action, and so ill give you a second to look through them and have some questions for you later. you can let me know when youve looked through them and understand them- the concept of all three of them.
Response: okay.

Call: okay so before we get started on that, i have to ask you: are there any cartoons or animated movies that you personally like? try to list them off, what are some of them?
Response: sure. well were a big animation fam so of course, disney and pixar. we actually have a lot of anime as well. anything from pokmon to avatar.

Call: so youre big on animation?
Response: yeah. our family is, yeah.

Call: so all of the above?
Response: pretty much.

Call: okay so based on the styles you see, the three options, which one would you choose? which one do you like the most, more so?
Response: personally? or which one do i think should be used in a video for kids?

Call: personally.
Response: personally, i like line art best of these three.

Call: line art. why does it appeal to you the most?
Response: simplified. gets the point across. its just less distracting.

Call: okay, so its clear and concise. it sounds like you had two options
Response: vector art would be the second.

Call: vector art would be your second option? okay, so it sounds like you had two options: you had a personal option and one for children if you could choose that one. so which one would you choose for children if you had the option?
Response: theyd probably take better to vector art.

Call: okay and why do you think that is?
Response: its more common to what they see. they dont see a lot of the line art. the doodles and stuff like that.

Call: okay, thats good to know. what do you think the take home messages from the video should be?
Response: trying to get them excited about coming. it has to be honest, that its not easy, like theres going to be work to it, but its all worth it to give it a try.

Call: sounds good, and is there anything you feel like i missed? anything important that i havent asked about that you feel we need to take into account?
Response: i dont think so. i mentioned the whole confidentiality part, because kids are often afraid to say something. i cant think of anything else.
